questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the office because of muscle pain in his upper and lower extremities. He has been having a hard time raising his arms above his head for the past few days. The patient also reports that he easily gets fatigued and it is difficult for him to climb the stairs to his apartment. Past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia. He was recently started on a low-fat diet and rosuvastatin to help reduce his blood cholesterol levels. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows weakness and soreness of proximal muscles of upper and lower extremities. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated levels of serum creatine phosphokinase. Rosuvastatin is immediately discontinued and the patient is started on a new lipid lowering drug which interferes with the action of circulating proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9). Which of the following best describes the function of PCSK9?

choices.text: Conversion of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA to mevalonate
Degradation of low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDL-R) on liver cells
Hydrolysis of extracellular triglycerides in lipoprotein
Hydrolysis of intracellular of triglycerides in adipose tissue

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from statin-induced myopathy and is switched to a new and safer drug that inhibits the activity of PCSK9 (e.g., alirocumab, evolocumab).

PCSK9 is a serine protease, predominantly produced in the liver. It binds to the low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDL-R) on the surface of hepatocytes and leads to its degradation, thereby resulting in elevated blood cholesterol levels. PCSK9 inhibitors are antibodies that bind PCSK9 and prevent LDL-R degradation. This leads to an overall increase in LDL-R on hepatocytes which results in a major decrease in serum LDL (by increasing its uptake in hepatocytes) and is indicated in patients with elevated LDL cholesterol. PCSK9 inhibitors are also shown to decrease the incidence of cardiovascular events in susceptible individuals. It is available as a subcutaneous injection and must be administered every 2-4 weeks. It is a comparatively safe lipid-lowering drug with occasional injection site reactions (pruritus, rash) and rare neurocognitive toxicity (delirium, dementia). Muscle toxicity, however, is not observed.  

Option Analysis

❌ Conversion of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA to mevalonate:
Incorrect: Hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase converts HMG CoA to mevalonate, which is a precursor of cholesterol. This enzyme is inhibited by statins and it results in decreased formation of cholesterol, thereby increasing the LDL receptors on hepatocytes and increasing the uptake of serum LDL.  
✅ Degradation of low-density lipoprotein receptors (LDL-R) on liver cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hydrolysis of extracellular triglycerides in lipoprotein:
Incorrect: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) hydrolyzes extracellular triglycerides in lipoproteins to free fatty acids and monoglycerides. LPL activity is up-regulated via the activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) by fibrates.  
❌ Hydrolysis of intracellular of triglycerides in adipose tissue:
Incorrect: Hormone-sensitive lipase hydrolyzes intracellular triglycerides in adipose tissue to free fatty acids. It is stimulated by catecholamines, ACTH, and glucagon and inhibited by niacin (vitamin B3) which is sometimes indicated in the management of dyslipidemia.  
❌ Degradation of monoaminergic neurotransmitters:
Incorrect: Monoamine oxidase is responsible for the degradation of monoaminergic neurotransmitters (catecholamine, dopamine and serotonin) in the synaptic cleft. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors prevent the degradation of monoamines and are used in the treatment of major depressive disorder. It does not affect the serum lipid levels.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the office for routine follow-up and has no active complaints at this visit. She was recently diagnosed with hypertriglyceridemia and was started on a low-fat diet along with fenofibrate. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Current medications include fenofibrate and lisinopril. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her father. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Repeat lipid panel revealed a triglyceride level of 900 mg/dL which was 1100 mg/dL a few weeks ago. A new supplement is added to her diet which decreases triglyceride levels by reducing the production of hepatic very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) cholesterol. Which of the following nutrients is present in these supplements?
questions.solution:
This patient with hypertriglyceridemia is prescribed an omega-3 fatty acid supplementation which reduces serum triglyceride (TG) levels. Eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid are two common omega-3 fatty acids which decrease both fasting and postprandial TGs by reducing the hepatic VLDL production. The exact mechanism is not known but a number of theories had been proposed, which include:
 
  •  Blockade of the enzyme responsible for TG synthesis in the liver (diacylglycerol acyltransferase or    phosphatidic acid phosphohydrolase) 
  •  Increased plasma lipoprotein lipase activity 
  •  Decreased lipogenesis in the liver 
  •  Increase β oxidation of fatty acids 
It is typically indicated in patients with hypertriglyceridemia (TG > 150 mg/dL). It also helps with improving blood pressure and cardiac function. Common adverse effects include gastrointestinal (GI) upset, fish-like taste and a possible increase in low-density lipoprotein (LDL).  

Option Analysis

❌ Niacin:
Incorrect: Niacin (vitamin B3) is used as a lipid lowering agent that acts by inhibiting hormone sensitive lipase in the adipose tissue, thereby preventing the mobilization of triglycerides. Although it reduces hepatic VLDL synthesis, its major role is to increase high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and is not used primarily in hypertriglyceridemia.  
✅ Omega 3 fatty acids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Retinoic acid:
Incorrect: Retinoic acid also known as vitamin A, is an antioxidant and is used primarily in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia and severe acne as all-trans retinoic acid and isotretinoin, respectively. It has no known effect on triglyceride levels.  
❌ Folate:
Incorrect: Folate (vitamin B9) plays an important role in the synthesis of nitrogenous bases in DNA and RNA. Its supplementation is helpful in pregnant women and patients with megaloblastic anemia. No effect on lipid metabolism is observed.  
❌ Ascorbic acid:
Incorrect: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant that facilitates iron absorption in the intestine by reducing it to Fe+2. No effect on lipid metabolism is seen.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic to evaluate elevated deposits around the eyes. The deposits developed for a year and are now affecting her physical appearance. Past medical history is significant for a syphilitic chancre, which was adequately treated with an antibiotic. Family history is significant for the death of the patient's mother from a massive myocardial infarction at the age of 42. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals the findings below. A fasting lipid profile is performed, and the results are shown below. In addition to dietary modification, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Laboratory Value
Results
Total cholesterol
375 mg/dL
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)
240 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
35 mg/dL
Triglycerides
100 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has xanthelasma around the eyes, a family history of premature coronary artery disease, and laboratory evidence of hypercholesterolemia. She is most likely suffering from familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the LDL receptor (LDL-R) gene. The mutation leads to increased levels of LDL-cholesterol and total cholesterol levels in the blood. Such individuals are at increased risk of premature cardiovascular disease, often beginning between 30 and 40 years of age.

FH is typically treated with statins, lipid-lowering drugs that competitively inhibit HMG-CoA reductase and lead to decreased hepatic cholesterol synthesis and increased LDL recycling. The overall effect is a significant reduction in LDL levels, a modest reduction in TG levels, and a moderate increase in HDL levels. Moreover, statins help decrease the risk of cardiovascular mortality in susceptible patients by decreasing serum cholesterol levels.

Indications for starting statin therapy are as follows:
  
  • LDL ≥ 190 mg/dL 
  • Clinically significant atherosclerotic disease (e.g., acute coronary syndrome, myocardial infarction, stroke, and transient ischemic attack) 
  • Diabetes mellitus in patients aged 40-75 years 
  • Estimated 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk ≥ 7.5% 

Option Analysis

✅ Atorvastatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cholestyramine:
Incorrect: Cholestyramine is a bile acid resin that helps decrease LDL cholesterol by binding bile acids in the intestine and preventing their reabsorption at the intestinal brush border. However, it does not appear to mitigate the risk of cardiovascular complications associated with hypercholesterolemia.  
❌ Ezetimibe:
Incorrect: Ezetimibe is a drug that lowers circulating cholesterol levels by decreasing cholesterol absorption in the small intestine. While it can help reduce this patient’s total cholesterol level, it does not mitigate the risk of cardiovascular complications associated with hypercholesterolemia.  
❌ Gemfibrozil:
Incorrect: A fibrate, such as gemfibrozil, would not be the appropriate first-line medication for this patient. Fibrates work by acting as ligands to the PPAR-α receptor and primarily lower VLDL without affecting LDL levels.  
❌ Omega-3-fatty acids:
Incorrect: Omega-3 fatty acid is not an appropriate first-line medication for this patient's condition. This drug is primarily used for lowering triglyceride levels, which are normal in this patient.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office for a routine follow-up. He has been feeling healthy and has no concerns. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in his father. The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes daily but does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 125/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows a well-appearing male with no abnormal findings. Laboratory testing is obtained, and the results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)
190 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
35 mg/dL
Triglyceride (TG)
100 mg/dL
Hemoglobin A1c
6.4%
Serum creatinine
1.2 mg/dL

choices.text: Schedule patient for a follow-up visit in 12-months

questions.solution:
Statins are an important part of the management plan in patients with significantly elevated LDL cholesterol levels and those at increased risk of cardiovascular mortality (e.g., diabetes and age >40 years).

Statins act by competitively inhibiting the hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase, which normally converts HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a cholesterol precursor. Of note, the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate is the rate-limiting step of cholesterol metabolism. As a result, statins decrease hepatic cholesterol synthesis and increase low-density lipoproteins (LDL) recycling via the upregulation of LDL receptors on hepatocytes.

A baseline workup is necessary before starting statin therapy to help monitor the treatment response and identify potential side effects. These include:
 
  • Serum creatine kinase (CPK) to determine baseline levels 
  • Lipid profile to monitor treatment response 
  • Liver function test (LFT) for potential hepatotoxicity.  
  • Thyroid function test (TFT) as myopathy can be aggravated in patients with hypothyroidism who are taking statins 
  • Renal function tests are not routinely indicated but should be obtained in patients with chronic kidney disease. 
If patients develop aminotransferase levels exceeding three times the upper limit of normal, then immediate discontinuation or dose reduction of the medication is indicated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate atorvastatin therapy:
Incorrect: This patient’s LDL levels are elevated and can benefit from statin therapy. However, baseline labs should be obtained before starting statin therapy.  
✅ Perform liver function testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Replace metformin with glimepiride:
Incorrect: This patient’s HbA1c is within the target goal (<7%). As a result, there is no need to replace metformin with glimepiride.  
❌ Schedule patient for a follow-up visit in 12-months:
Incorrect: Although this patient is currently asymptomatic, his lipid profile shows significantly elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. The patient should be started on statin therapy after baseline labs have been obtained.  
❌ Prescribe vitamin E supplements:
Incorrect: This patient’s LDL levels are significantly elevated, and vitamin E supplements have no proven benefit in managing lipid disorders.

questions.text:
A 94-year-old man presents to the primary care physician for a routine evaluation accompanied by his son. He has no medical concerns and feels well, though he reports decreased urine output over the past 2 days. The patient was recently seen in the emergency department for a fall and closed head injury but has otherwise been living independently. He has a past medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, and dementia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 136/64 mmHg, heart rate is 77 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination are within normal limits. Mucous membranes appear dry. The patient is alert and oriented to self and place, which is the patient's baseline. Laboratory results are displayed below. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further history?  

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 151 mEq/L
 Potassium 4.8 mEq/L
 Chloride 97 mEq/L
 Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL

choices.text: Surgical correction of an obstructive uropathy

questions.solution:
This patient presents with asymptomatic hypernatremia, associated with decreased urine output and dry mucous membranes, suggestive of hypovolemic hyponatremia. In the older adult population, this condition is often secondary to inadequate fluid intake due to impaired thirst mechanisms or limited access to water.

Hypernatremia is an electrolyte imbalance where serum sodium concentration exceeds 145 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L). It can be classified based on onset (acute or chronic) and volume status (hypovolemic, euvolemic, or hypervolemic).

Historical factors associated with hypernatremia depend on the underlying cause. For example, patients with hypovolemic hyponatremia may report a history suggestive of volume losses, recent diuretic use, or inadequate fluid intake. Clinical findings of volume depletion, such as dry mucous membranes or orthostatic hypotension, may be present. Those with euvolemic hypernatremia may report polydipsia or polyuria and will generally appear hydrated on examination. Patients with hypervolemic hypernatremia will have signs of volume overload, such as shortness of breath and peripheral edema.

Option Analysis

✅ Low fluid intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent hypertonic saline administration:
Incorrect: Hypertonic saline is typically used to treat acute, severe hyponatremia and would most likely result in a rapid and significant increase in serum sodium. This would typically present with severe neurological symptoms, such as seizure or coma. This patient is currently asymptomatic.
❌ Recent furosemide use:
Incorrect: Furosemide, a loop diuretic, can cause dehydration and subsequent hypernatremia; however, it is more likely to result in increased urine output (polyuria) rather than decreased urine output (oliguria), as observed in this patient.
❌ Recent mannitol administration:
Incorrect: Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic, can raise serum sodium levels. However, it is typically associated with increased urine output (polyuria), not decreased urine output (oliguria).
❌ Surgical correction of an obstructive uropathy:
Incorrect: Surgical correction of obstructive uropathy can result in post-obstructive diuresis and hypernatremia. However, this patient does not have a history of prostate disease or any symptoms indicative of obstructive uropathy. Additionally, the patient has experienced a decrease in urine output, not an increase.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office for routine follow-up. He was diagnosed with dyslipidemia 6 months ago on a fasting lipid panel. He has no active complaints at this visit. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily, drinks 2-3 beers on weekends and does not use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. His BMI is 32.5 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A repeat fasting lipid panel was obtained during today’s visit. Comparison of the results is shown below. The physician counseled him about dietary modifications and decided to add another lipid-lowering drug to this patient’s medication regimen which inhibits bile acid reabsorption in the intestine. Which of the following is the most likely medication this patient was started on?  

Laboratory value
6 months ago
Today
Total cholesterol
370 mg/dL
301 mg/dL
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)  
250 mg/dL
175 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)  
30 mg/dL
33 mg/dL
Triglycerides (TGs)  
90 mg/dL
89 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has hypercholesterolemia which is not significantly improving with mono-therapy with statins (atorvastatin). The new drug added to his regime is a bile acid resin, common examples of which include cholestyramine, colestipol and colesevelam.

Bile acid resins are large, positively-charged molecules that bind to the negatively-charged bile acid in the intestine, inhibiting reabsorption at the intestinal brush border. The liver compensates for the decreased bile acids by increasing the production of bile salts via its up-regulation of LDL receptor and an increase in the synthesis of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase (which converts HMG CoA to mevalonate, a cholesterol precursor). Bile acid resins are not as effective as statins, which increase the LDL receptors and inhibit HMG-CoA, and that is why they are usually used in combination with statins. The LDL receptors also very slightly increase the uptake of VLDL. A minor increase in HDL levels is also observed. Its combination with a non-statin lipid-lowering agent (e.g., niacin, fibrates) may be useful in patients who are statin-intolerant and require intensive lipid-lowering therapy. Common adverse effects associated with bile acid resins include gastrointestinal upset (nausea, bloating and cramping) and impaired absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K) and drugs (e.g., digoxin, warfarin).  

Option Analysis

❌ Niacin:
Incorrect:  Niacin, a lipid lowering drug, acts to prevent lipolysis by inhibiting hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue. Its overall effect is a major increase in HDL and a decrease in LDL. It, however, does not affect intestinal absorption of bile acids.  
✅ Cholestyramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fenofibrate:
Incorrect: This drug is a fibrate that activates PPAR-α, causing the up-regulation of lipoprotein lipase levels to increase the clearance of serum triglycerides. This class of drugs also decreases very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) and induces HDL synthesis. It has no effect on bile acid reabsorption.  
❌ Ezetimibe:
Incorrect: Ezetimibe inhibits cholesterol (not bile acid) absorption at the intestinal brush border, reducing liver cholesterol stores and decreasing biliary bile content.  
❌ Alirocumab:
Incorrect: Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that acts by inhibiting the degradation of LDL-R, facilitating the removal of LDL from the bloodstream. No effect on intestinal bile acid absorption is observed with the use of this drug.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic to discuss concerns about his weight. Over the past year, the patient has unintentionally lost 15 lb. (6.8 kg). He has not started any new medication. He has no fevers, chills, night sweats, insomnia, or anhedonia. The patient has a bowel movement daily and frequently has two loose bowel movements per week. His past medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease stage 1 and well-controlled major depressive disorder. Current medication includes citalopram and multivitamins. The patient lives in an apartment attached to the home of his daughter and her family, whom he sees often. Vital signs are within normal limits. His current weight is 142 lb. (64.4 kg). On physical examination, the patient has temporal wasting and poor extremity muscle mass. He has dentures in place which fall out of his mouth several times during the exam. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 0.35 µU/mL and free T4 is 1.4 ng/dL. Which of the following elements is the most probable cause of this patient’s unintentional weight loss?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with significant unintentional weight loss and is found to have poorly fitting dentures during history and physical. The rest of his history, physical examination, and evaluation does not suggest an alternate cause, making impaired caloric intake from an oropharyngeal condition the most probable cause.    

Unintentional weight loss refers to a weight loss >5% of body weight over 6-12 months in a patient not actively trying to lose weight. The differential is extremely broad. It can be due to medication side effects, socioeconomic barriers, or underlying medical conditions. Underlying medical conditions can be further broken down into increased metabolic demand, impaired caloric intake, or impaired absorption.    

For patients with unintentional weight loss history, it is often the most useful tool in making a diagnosis. A thorough medication review should be performed to assess for medication side effects that can lead to weight loss. Discussion with the patient should include an assessment of socioeconomic barriers such as isolation, functional limitations, financial barriers, and poor access to transportation. Patients should also be screened for depression and dementia in older patients. If none of these factors are present, then history and physical should focus on determining the underlying medical condition. Patients with gastrointestinal disorders may have symptoms such as abdominal discomfort, bloating, nausea, early satiety, or diarrhea. Patients should be assessed for oropharyngeal pain, dysphagia, or poorly fitting dentures in cases of impaired caloric intake. If none of these are present, then a thorough review of systems, physical examination, and laboratory work can help determine the underlying medical condition leading to increased metabolic demands.  

 



Option Analysis

✅ Poorly fitting dentures:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Loose bowel movements:
Incorrect: Significant diarrhea may be a sign of malabsorption (e.g., Celiac disease, chronic pancreatitis). This patient frequently has two loose bowel movements per week; considering otherwise normal bowel movements, the loose stool is not significant enough to represent malabsorption, leading to weight loss. 
❌ Chronic kidney disease:
Incorrect: Chronic advanced kidney disease, like other chronic and advanced medical diseases, is associated with weight loss from increased metabolic demands. However, stage 1 chronic kidney disease would not significantly contribute to weight loss. 
❌ Antidepressant use:
Incorrect: While untreated depression can lead to weight loss (or weight gain), this patient’s major depressive disorder is well-controlled. In addition, antidepressants tend to lead to weight gain and not weight loss. 
❌ Abnormal thyroid studies :
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism can lead to increased metabolism and thus weight loss. This patient’s TSH is minimally decreased but serum-free T4 is normal, ruling out hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a fall. She has not had any recent fever, joint pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain. A family member at the bedside states the patient has been depressed and more forgetful for the past several months. She has also unintentionally lost 20-lb. in the past year. The patient has no known past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0 ºC, pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/81 mmHg. Current BMI is 19 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented to person and place, but not to time, and has frequent difficulty with word finding and repeating words. There are no extra heart sounds on auscultation and the lungs sound clear on both sides. There is mild epigastric tenderness to palpation. There is asymmetric joint hypertrophy at the distal joints in both hands with minimal tenderness. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s weight loss?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with unintentional weight loss, forgetfulness, impaired orientation, and a depressed mood. With an otherwise unremarkable physical examination, these findings together suggest a neuropsychiatric condition (e.g., cognitive impairment or dementia) as the cause of her unintentional weight loss.   

Unintentional weight loss refers to a weight loss >5% of body weight over 6-12 months in a patient not actively trying to lose weight. The differential is overly broad and can be due to medication side effects, socioeconomic barriers, or underlying medical conditions. Underlying medical conditions can be further broken down into increased metabolic demand, impaired caloric intake, or impaired absorption.    For patients with unintentional weight loss, a thorough medication review and assessment for socioeconomic barriers are imperative. If an underlying medical condition is suspected, then the history, physical, review of systems, and laboratory/imaging studies can help determine the underlying cause.   

Patients with neuropsychiatric conditions can also develop unintentional weight loss. All patients should be screened for depression (generally with a PHQ-2, patient health questionnaire form) if they present with any concerning symptoms such as depressed mood, fatigue, and anhedonia. Older patients should be screened for dementia with a mini-mental status exam. They may present with confusion, memory loss, or mood changes, and physical examination may show aphasia or apraxia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Neuropsychiatric condition:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Upper gastrointestinal tract condition:
Incorrect: While this patient does not have an obvious reason for the mild epigastric discomfort, the lack of any other gastrointestinal symptoms makes this unlikely to be a significant cause of weight loss. A gastrointestinal cause of weight loss should be suspected in patients with early satiety, vomiting, dysphagia, or other symptoms. 
❌ Autoimmune condition:
Incorrect: Autoimmune diseases can lead to a hyperinflammatory state and increased metabolic demands, leading to weight loss. This patient’s hand arthritis is likely due to osteoarthritis, and she has no fever or rash to suggest an autoimmune condition. 
❌ Chronic cardiopulmonary disease:
Incorrect: Chronic advanced cardiopulmonary disease leads to unintentional weight loss due to increased metabolic demand. This patient has no past medical history and has a normal cardiopulmonary exam and no peripheral edema, which makes cardiopulmonary disease an unlikely cause of her weight loss. 
❌ Gastrointestinal malabsorption:
Incorrect: Malabsorption can lead to significant weight loss. However, this patient has no nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, to suggest malabsorption.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status and generalized seizure activity. The patient was found by a family member next to an empty quart of soy sauce. The patient has a past medical history of anxiety, depression, and schizophrenia with previous suicide attempts. The patient takes risperidone, sertraline, and lorazepam as needed. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), blood pressure is 166/64 mmHg, heart rate is 97 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears postictal and stuporous. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. The patient moves all extremities spontaneously. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 172 mEq/L
 Potassium 4.8 mEq/L
 Chloride 100 mEq/L
 Creatinine 2.9 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of acute, life-threatening hypernatremia, including seizures, due to an excess salt load. Acute management involves administration of a hypotonic solution, like dextrose 5% in water (D5W). This will correct the electrolyte imbalance. Emergent hemodialysis may be considered as an alternative, particularly in cases of concurrent oliguric acute kidney injury.

Hypernatremia is an electrolyte imbalance characterized by a serum sodium concentration exceeding 145 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L). It typically results from increased water loss or decreased water intake but can also be caused by an excess salt load, as in this case. Hypernatremia is classified based on onset (acute or chronic) and volume status (hypovolemic, euvolemic, or hypervolemic).

Acute management begins with an ABCDE (airway, breathing, circulation, disability, exposure) assessment to determine if the patient is stable or unstable. Unstable patients, often presenting with symptoms like seizure or coma, require immediate stabilization with IV access, continuous vital sign monitoring, and potential airway support (e.g., intubation, mechanical ventilation). A Foley catheter should be placed to monitor urine output, and a hypotonic solution should be administered. Unlike chronic hypernatremia, which requires gradual correction to avoid complications, severe acute hypernatremia (particularly due to salt poisoning) should be corrected more quickly to prevent further neurological damage.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741 or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone. 

Option Analysis

✅ Dextrose 5% in water (D5W):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lactated ringers (LR):
Incorrect: LR is an isotonic solution and would not provide the free water necessary to address this patient’s severe, acute hypernatremia. In this scenario, hypotonic solutions, like D5W, would be preferred.
❌ Normal saline:
Incorrect: Normal saline is an isotonic solution and would not provide the free water necessary to address this patient’s severe, acute hypernatremia. In this scenario, hypotonic solutions, like D5W, would be preferred.
❌ Hypertonic 3% saline:
Incorrect: Hypertonic saline is used to treat acute, symptomatic hyponatremia, not hypernatremia. Administration of this agent could potentially worsen this patient's condition.
❌ Intravenous (IV) lorazepam:
Incorrect: IV lorazepam is used for the acute treatment of seizures and status epilepticus. Since this patient is postictal and not currently having a seizure, lorazepam is not necessary. The underlying cause of the seizure (i.e. acute hypernatremia) should be addressed with free water administration, such as D5W.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman is evaluated in the intensive care unit (ICU) following a traumatic intracranial hemorrhage. The patient was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident and sustained a closed head injury with subarachnoid hemorrhage. There is no other significant medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 126/64 mmHg, heart rate is 87 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on the ventilator. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Mucous membranes are moist. Laboratory results are detailed below. The patient’s urine osmolality increases by 55% one hour after administration of intravenous (IV) desmopressin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 151 mEq/L
 Potassium 3.9 mEq/L
 Chloride 99 mEq/L
 Urine osmolality 210 mOsm/kg
 Plasma osmolality 330 mOsm/kg
 Urine output 64 mL/Kg/24 hours
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of recent traumatic brain injury, has developed hypernatremia and appears euvolemic on physical examination. The elevated urine output, high plasma osmolality, and inappropriately low urine osmolality are consistent with diabetes insipidus (DI). A positive desmopressin challenge test is diagnostic of central DI.

Hypernatremia is an electrolyte imbalance that occurs when serum sodium concentration exceeds 145 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L). Once hypernatremia is confirmed on a chemistry panel, further workup depends on the likely underlying cause. This can be narrowed by determining whether the patient is hypervolemic, euvolemic, or hypovolemic. Patients with hypovolemic hyponatremia may report volume losses, recent diuretic use, or inadequate fluid intake. These patients should have urine output and urine osmolality measured.

Patients with euvolemic hypernatremia may endorse polydipsia or polyuria and will appear hydrated on examination. Urine output and urine and plasma osmolality should be obtained. Differentiating central DI from nephrogenic GI can be achieved via a desmopressin challenge.

Patients with hypervolemic hypernatremia will demonstrate signs of volume overload, such as shortness of breath or peripheral edema. Measuring urine sodium and creatinine to calculate a fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) can help differentiate excess salt load from primary aldosteronism. The table below summarizes key findings for important causes of hypernatremia.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Central diabetes insipidus (DI):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI):
Incorrect: Nephrogenic DI occurs when the kidneys fail to respond to vasopressin (ADH). Unlike central DI, patients with nephrogenic DI typically show little to no increase in urine osmolality in response to desmopressin.
❌ Mannitol administration:
Incorrect: Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic, can increase urine output and lower urine osmolality. However, the urine osmolality would not increase with a desmopressin challenge.
❌ Primary aldosteronism:
Incorrect: Primary aldosteronism is a cause of hypervolemic hypernatremia that presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and volume overload. This patient is euvolemic on exam, and primary aldosteronism is associated with normal plasma osmolality. Additionally, urine osmolality would not increase with a desmopressin challenge.
❌ Insensible losses:
Incorrect: Insensible losses (e.g., fever, excessive sweating) can contribute to hypovolemic hypernatremia. However, such losses typically present with low urine output and high urine osmolality. Additionally, this patient appears euvolemic on exam.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of developmental delay and poor performance in school. She recently received a prescription for glasses due to an inability to see the blackboard. She is currently in special education classes for learning disabilities. The family immigrated from Ethiopia 2 years ago. A review of her development reveals delayed attainment of milestones. Her weight at the 50th percentile for her age, while her height is at the 90th percentile. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the patient reveals a tall, thin habitus with elongated limbs. Ophthalmic examination reveals bilateral inferior lens dislocations. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Urine cyanide nitroprusside test is positive. Supplementation of which of the following vitamins is likely to improve this patient’s clinical outcome?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with developmental delay, marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test. This presentation is suggestive of a diagnosis of homocystinuria.

Homocystine is an intermediary amino acid formed from the metabolism of methionine to cysteine. Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive condition that results in elevated levels of homocysteine in plasma and urine due to imparied methionine metabolism. It can be classified into familial or acquired forms of the disease. Familial homocystinuria can result from cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency, methionine synthase deficiency, or decreased affinity of pyridoxal phosphate to cystathionine synthase.






The presenting symptom in most adolescents and children is developmental delay. Other clinical manifestations include marfanoid features, lens dislocation (downward and inward), osteoporosis, kyphosis, and premature atherosclerosis. Complications include thrombotic events such as transient ischemic attacks, stroke, angina and myocardial infarctions, and venous thromboembolic events.







Diagnosis is made by detecting elevated homocysteine levels in blood and urine and a positive urine cyanide nitroprusside test that detects amino acids containing sulfur.  Treatment of homocystinuria varies depending on the underlying biochemical defect and the severity of the defect. Supplementation of folate, cobalamin (vitamin B12), and pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is sufficient to lower homocysteine levels in most patients.

Option Analysis

✅ Cobalamin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thiamine:
Incorrect:  Thiamine is supplemented in the treatment of maple syrup urine disease, as it serves as a cofactor for the deficient enzyme branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase. It classically presents with severe neurological deterioration, dystonia, and developmental delay. This patient’s presentation with marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and developmental delay suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Riboflavin:
Incorrect: Riboflavin deficiency manifests with cheilosis, corneal vascularisation, and stomatitis. This patient’s presentation with marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and developmental delay suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Ascorbic acid:
Incorrect: Scurvy is characterized by bleeding gums, petechiae, and subperiosteal hemorrhages and is treated with vitamin C (ascorbic acid) supplementation. Absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Tetrahydrobiopterin:
Incorrect: Malignant phenylketonuria results from a deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin and clinically manifests with symptoms of neurologic deterioration and hypopigmentation. BH4 supplementation is advised in malignant phenylketonuria. This patient’s presentation with marfanoid habitus, lens dislocation, and developmental delay suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 48-hour-old male neonate is under evaluation in the neonatal ICU for an episode of a seizure. Since starting breastfeeding, he has been irritable, has been feeding poorly, and has had several episodes of vomiting. He was born at 40 weeks gestation to a 35-year-old woman following an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 145/min, and respiratory rate is 34/min. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Neurological examination reveals intermittent cycling movements in his lower extremities.   Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated serum levels of leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Supplementation of which of the following could be considered in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Elevated serum levels of branched-chain amino acids, along with symptoms of neurologic deterioration, is suggestive of a diagnosis of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).



MSUD is caused by an inability to break down branched-chain amino acids, including leucine, isoleucine and valine, due to branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency. During the catabolism of these branched-chain amino acids, metabolites are formed which are then metabolized by branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase, generating products that eventually enter the Krebs cycle, ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis. Decarboxylation of these alpha-keto acids is mediated by thiamine pyrophosphate, a cofactor containing thiamine (vitamin B1).



The clinical manifestations of MSUD result from the accumulation of these branched-chain amino acids in the CNS, liver, and skeletal muscle. Metabolic products of leucine interfere with the transport of other amino acids across the blood brain barrier, particularly those involved in the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as serotonin and dopamine. The presence of a derivative of leucine, alloisoleucine, contributes to the sweet maple syrup odor of urine in these patients. Classic MSUD is the most common form of the disorder and presents in the early neonatal period with irritability, dystonia, vomiting, poor feeding and detection of ketonuria.

Diagnosis is made by detecting branched-chain amino acids in the analysis of serum samples and urine. Treatment is directed at restricting dietary intake of branched-amino acids and thiamine supplementation. Hemodialysis may be used in severe cases.

Option Analysis

✅ Thiamine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vitamin B12:
Incorrect: Cobalamin deficiency is characterized by macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia and neurologic findings which include subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord and peripheral neuropathy. Vitamin B12 deficiency may cause elevated levels of homocysteine, but it would not result in elevated levels of leucine, isoleucine and valine.
❌ Pyridoxine:
Incorrect: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is advised with administration of isoniazid to prevent peripheral neuropathy. There is no indication for pyridoxine in this patient. 
❌ Tetrahydrobiopterin:
Incorrect: Malignant phenylketonuria results from a deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) and clinically manifests with symptoms of neurologic deterioration and hypopigmentation. BH4 supplementation is advised in malignant phenylketonuria. However, PKU results in elevated phenylalanine levels in serum, not branched-chain amino acids (e.g., leucine, valine, isoleucine).
❌ Arginine:
Incorrect: Urea cycle disorders respond to arginine supplementation, as it promotes disposal of nitrogenous wastes. Urea cycle disorders do not lead to elevated levels of branched-chain amino acids.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the primary care office with her parent for a sports physical. She recently recovered from stress fractures of her 4th and 5th metatarsals. She has no residual symptoms and follow-up x-ray demonstrated complete resolution. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) was done after the fractures and her Z-score was -2.0. The patient participates in gymnastics 5-6 days per week. She has never had a concussion and does not experience exertional symptoms with exercise. There is no family history of sudden cardiac death. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mmHg. Height is 5 ft 1 inch (154.9 cm), weight is 83 lbs (37.6 kg), body mass index is 15.7 kg/m2 (4th percentile for her age). On examination, the patient is alert and conversant. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs, gallops, or bruits. Pulmonary exam is within normal limits. The feet are non-tender bilaterally with full range of motion of all joints. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following additional clinical findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient experienced metatarsal stress fractures in the setting of decreased bone mineral density (BMD). Given her age, low body mass index (BMI), and active participation in gymnastics, the female athlete triad is the most likely diagnosis. The third clinical feature of the female athlete triad is menstrual dysfunction, making amenorrhea the most likely additional clinical finding in this patient.         

Assessing BMI is an important part of the sports physical. Low BMI can suggest conditions such as disordered eating or female athlete triad. The female athlete triad is a phenomenon characterized by low energy availability from decreased caloric intake or excessive energy expenditure (with or without disordered eating); menstrual dysfunction; and decreased BMI. Biologically, female athletes who participate in sports that emphasize leanness, such as endurance running, ballet, and gymnastics, are especially susceptible to the female athlete triad. These athletes, and those with disordered eating, may still be able to participate in sports, but they may require psychiatric and other medical assessments before it is safe to do so.        

Additional items to ask about when doing a sports physical include history of previous injuries or concussions; screening for signs and symptoms of cardiovascular disease in the patient, family history of genetic cardiac conditions, history of sudden or unexplained cardiac death; screening for mental health conditions and substance abuse including use of performance-enhancing substances. The physical examination should include BMI, blood pressure, vision and hearing, a head-to-toe musculoskeletal and basic neurologic exam, complete cardiac exam including distal pulses, assessment for phenotypic features of Marfan syndrome, and a chaperoned testicular exam in biologically male patients.    

Option Analysis

✅ Amenorrhea:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acne:
Incorrect: Acne can be seen in conditions of androgen excess, which can cause amenorrhea; however, this patient has a decreased body mass index (BMI) and low bone mineral density (BMD) which are consistent with the female athlete triad of low energy availability, menstrual dysfunction, and decreased BMD.  
❌ Hirsutism :
Incorrect: Hirsutism may be seen in states of androgen excess, which can cause amenorrhea, but patients with androgen excess typically present with central weight gain. This patient has a low body mass index and signs and symptoms consistent with the female athlete’s triad of low energy availability, menstrual dysfunction, and decreased BMD.   
❌ Pectus excavatum:
Incorrect: Pectus excavatum is a phenotypic feature that may be seen in Marfan syndrome. Additional clinical manifestations of Marfan syndrome include tall stature, arachnodactyly, cardiac anomalies, and an abnormally long arm span. This patient does not have clinical features suggestive of Marfan syndrome, making pectus excavatum unlikely to be seen on physical exam.  
❌ Tachycardia :
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation and findings are consistent with the female athlete triad. Bradycardia, not tachycardia, is an associated finding with the female athlete triad.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy presents to the office with four weeks of diarrhea. The parent reports that the stool is foul-smelling, bulky, and greasy. The Infant was born full term without complications and passed meconium at three days of life. Newborn screening results are unknown. There is no history of vomiting, choking, or increased work of breathing with feeds. History is significant for a diagnosis of pneumonia requiring hospital admission at four months of age. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Weight has dropped from the 55<sup>th</sup> percentile to the 7<sup>th</sup> percentile. Length has dropped from the 30<sup>th</sup> percentile to the 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile. Physical examination reveals a pale thin-appearing infant without dysmorphic features or characteristic odors. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. A 2/6 flow murmur is appreciated best at the left lower sternal border. Which of the following can be used to confirm the underlying cause of growth faltering?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with growth faltering as indicated by weight-for-age crossing 2 major percentile lines. He has diarrhea, steatorrhea, a history of delayed meconium passage, and pneumonia requiring hospitalization at an early age. These findings are consistent with cystic fibrosis and a sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder of the exocrine glands that frequently leads to chronic sinopulmonary infections and pancreatic insufficiency. Newborns with CF may present with meconium ileus, prolonged neonatal jaundice, and early lung infections. Infants and children with CF may present with poor weight gain due to malabsorption, anemia, recurrent sinopulmonary infections, and distal intestinal obstructive syndrome.

The diagnostic workup of growth faltering begins with a history and physical examination to narrow down the cause of growth faltering, which can be due to increased energy expenditure, inadequate caloric intake, or malabsorption. Infants with CF can develop malabsorption secondary to pancreatic insufficiency which results in steatorrhea (bulky, greasy, foul-smelling stools), vitamin deficiencies, and growth faltering. All newborns are screened for CF as part of the standard newborn screening panel starting with immunoreactive trypsinogen (IRT). If a newborn screen returns with an elevated IRT level or there is clinical suspicion for CF, sweat chloride testing should be ordered. An elevated sweat chloride level is consistent with cystic fibrosis and should prompt genetic testing for CF. Two sweat chloride levels ≥ 60 mmol/L or a positive cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) mutation confirms the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Although a low fecal elastase indicates pancreatic insufficiency and malabsorption, it does confirm CF.

Option Analysis

❌ Fecal elastase levels :
Incorrect: This patient most likely has cystic fibrosis, and fecal elastase levels are typically low in patients with cystic fibrosis. They can be used to monitor pancreatic exocrine function. However, they are not used to confirm the diagnosis. A sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis.
❌ Chest radiograph :
Incorrect: While a chest x-ray can identify hyperinflation, bronchiectasis, and atelectasis in patients with cystic fibrosis, it is not used to make the diagnosis. A sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing cystic fibrosis.
❌ Serum tissue transglutaminase IgA (tTG igA) levels :
Incorrect: A positive tTG IgA is highly suggestive of celiac disease which can cause patients to have poor weight gain, diarrhea, steatorrhea, and a rash. The findings in this patient are more consistent with cystic fibrosis given the history of delayed passage of meconium and pneumonia at an early age. A sweat chloride test is the test of choice to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.
✅ Sweat chloride test :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upper endoscopy  :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy can be used to assess gastroesophageal reflux which can cause growth faltering. This patient most likely has cystic fibrosis, which is diagnosed by sweat chloride testing.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy is sent to the emergency department by the pediatrician for further evaluation of failure to thrive and laboratory abnormalities. The patient was born full-term without complications. Formula feeding has been established, but weight has dropped from the 48th to the 3rd percentile. The parents report a responsive smile but note difficulty with lifting the head during tummy time. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the infant is irritable and hypotonic with a round, doll-like face. There is a protruding abdomen and mild hepatomegaly. Examination is otherwise normal. Laboratory studies obtained three hours after a feed are shown below. Which of the following additional laboratory findings would be expected?

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Blood gas         
 pH     7.3    
 PaCO2     35 mmHg    
 HCO3     17 mEq/L    
 Serum chemistries         
 Lactic acid      4 mmol/L    
 Blood glucose      30 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This infant presents with failure to thrive, hypotonia, doll-like facies, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory evaluation reveals fasting hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. These findings are highly suggestive of glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I), also known as von Gierke disease. Hypertriglyceridemia is commonly seen in affected infants.

In the evaluation of hypoglycemia in infants, the timing of hypoglycemia in relation to feeding is a critical diagnostic clue. Postprandial hypoglycemia raises suspicion for inborn errors of carbohydrate metabolism, such as hereditary fructose intolerance or classic galactosemia. In contrast, fasting hypoglycemia accompanied by lactic acidosis suggests a defect in gluconeogenesis, such as fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase deficiency or GSD I. Molecular genetic testing can help distinguish between these conditions.

GSD I results from mutations affecting glucose-6-phosphatase activity. Infants typically present between two and six months of age with fasting hypoglycemia (often within two to three hours of a meal) and poor weight gain. Characteristic physical findings include doll-like facies, hepatosplenomegaly, hypotonia, and xanthomas. Laboratory abnormalities may include severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hypertriglyceridemia. Management focuses on preventing hypoglycemia through frequent feedings and supplementation with cornstarch.

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated creatine kinase levels:
Incorrect: Elevated creatine kinase levels are seen in infantile Pompe disease, a lysosomal storage disease. Affected infants typically present with cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hypotonia, and feeding difficulties. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
❌ Elevated leucine levels:
Incorrect: Elevated leucine levels are seen in patients with maple syrup urine disease. These patients can present as newborns with encephalopathy, sweet odor to the urine, and ketonuria. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
❌ Hyperammonemia:
Incorrect: Hyperammonemia suggests a urea cycle disorder, which typically presents with respiratory alkalosis and can lead to encephalopathy, seizures, and coma. This infant has metabolic acidosis and lactic acidosis, consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
❌ Hyperinsulinemia:
Incorrect: Hyperinsulinemia can cause neonatal hypoglycemia, particularly in infants born to diabetic mothers or those with congenital hyperinsulinism. However, these findings of failure to thrive, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, and characteristic facies are more consistent with glycogen storage disease type I, which is associated with hypertriglyceridemia.
✅ Hypertriglyceridemia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 1-month-old female infant is evaluated in the clinic during a 1-month-old well check. The infant is breastfed, but the parents note that she tires easily and sweats while feeding. She feeds 8-10 times a day, five minutes on each side, and latches well. There is no history of choking, coughing with feeding, diarrhea, or vomiting. Parents report frequent spit-ups that are nonbloody, nonbilious, not projectile and do not cause the infant discomfort. There is appropriate urine output and 6-8 diapers with stool every day. There is an older sibling at home who attends daycare and is frequently sick. The infant was born at full term with no complications during pregnancy or delivery. At birth, weight, length, and head circumference were at the 30th percentile. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 45/min, blood pressure is 82/45 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Weight and height are at less than the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile. Head circumference is at the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile. Physical examination reveals a calm infant in mild respiratory distress. No dysmorphic features are noted. There is tachypnea and faint diffuse crackles are appreciated on lung examination. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. No hepatosplenomegaly is appreciated. The patient is sent to the Emergency Department. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 1-month-old infant presents with growth faltering as diagnosed by a weight-for-age more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and biological sex. History is pertinent for tiring and sweating with feeding. On physical examination, there is tachycardia, tachypnea, crackles, and a holosystolic murmur. This patient’s growth faltering is most likely secondary to congenital heart disease, specifically a ventricular septal defect causing mild heart failure. Obtaining an echocardiogram is the best next step in the evaluation.

Growth faltering refers to the inability to gain or maintain adequate weight. It can result from underlying conditions associated with increased metabolic requirements like congenital heart disease, malabsorption, or inadequate caloric intake. When a pediatric patient presents with growth faltering, obtaining measurements of weight and height or length and plotting results on a standardized growth chart is the first step. If the patient’s weight-for-age or BMI is more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and biological sex or if the weight-for-age has crossed 2 major percentile lines, growth faltering is diagnosed.

A focused history and physical exam should assess for Chronic health conditions such as congenital heart diseases which can lead to growth faltering due to increased energy expenditure. Patients with Congenital heart diseases can present with increased work of breathing, sweating, or cyanosis with feeding. Physical exam may reveal findings such as a heart murmur and signs of congestive heart failure (e.g., hepatomegaly, tachypnea, and tachycardia). If findings are suggestive of congenital heart disease, an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Echocardiogram  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chest radiograph :
Incorrect: This patient has tachypnea and crackles on pulmonary examination, but these findings are secondary to heart failure. Although a chest radiograph can assess for cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion, an echocardiogram is the best next step in the evaluation of this patient’s growth faltering. It will provide information about the underlying heart defect and degree of heart failure. 
❌ Abdominal ultrasound  :
Incorrect: This patient is spitting up frequently but there are no red flags. She is a “happy spitter,” and no abdominal imaging is necessary. The tiring and sweating with feeding, tachypnea, crackles on pulmonary examination, and the presence of a holosystolic murmur make mild heart failure secondary to a ventricular septal defect the most likely diagnosis. This is best evaluated with an echocardiogram. 
❌ Stool studies :
Incorrect: This patient is having 6-8 stools a day which is normal for a 1-month-old. No further evaluation of the stools is necessary. The tiring and sweating with feeding, tachypnea, crackles on pulmonary examination, and holosystolic murmur make mild heart failure secondary to a ventricular septal defect the most likely diagnosis. This is best evaluated with an echocardiogram. 
❌ Evaluation of the caloric value of breastmilk :
Incorrect: Although the number of calories in breast milk varies per person there are ways to measure this value. However, this patient has mild heart failure, as evidenced by tiring and sweating with feeding, tachypnea, crackles on pulmonary examination, and the presence of a holosystolic murmur.  An echocardiogram is the best next step in management.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy, poor feeding, increased work of breathing, and vomiting. The infant was born at full term via vaginal delivery. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful, and prenatal labs were negative. After discharge, the infant was doing well; however, since yesterday, there has been progressive lethargy and difficulty with feeding. There has been non-bloody, non-bilious, non-projectile vomiting after feeds. The infant has had three wet diapers and one stool in the last 24 hours. Weight is down 12% from birth. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 65/min, blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical exam, the infant is lethargic, with moderate retractions and equal air entry bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. No nasal congestion is present. The abdomen is soft and nondistended with hepatomegaly. A complete blood count, inflammatory markers, glucose level, and chest x-ray are unremarkable. Respiratory viral panel is negative. Arterial blood gas is shown below. The anion gap is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to obtain next?

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Blood gas         
 pH     7.55    
 PaCO2     22 mmHg    
 HCO3     19 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This newborn presents with lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, and increased work of breathing. On exam, the infant is lethargic with tachypnea and moderate retractions. Arterial blood gas reveals respiratory alkalosis, which raises concern for a urea cycle disorder. The next appropriate step is to obtain a serum ammonia level.

When a pediatric patient presents with signs suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism, a focused history and physical examination should be performed, and key laboratory studies should be obtained. These include an arterial blood gas (ABG), complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), serum ammonia level, and urinalysis. An ABG showing elevated pH and decreased partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO₂) indicates respiratory alkalosis, which, in this context, is concerning for a urea cycle disorder. Marked hyperammonemia further supports this diagnosis.

Urea cycle disorders are characterized by impaired conversion of ammonia to urea, resulting in hyperammonemia. Elevated ammonia levels stimulate respiratory drive, leading to respiratory alkalosis. If untreated, hyperammonemia can cause encephalopathy, seizures, and coma. The most common urea cycle disorder is ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency. Plasma amino acid analysis can help confirm the diagnosis, with findings that typically include elevated glutamine and alanine levels, and decreased citrulline and arginine levels.

Option Analysis

❌ Air contrast enema:
Incorrect: An air contrast enema is useful for the management of intussusception, which typically presents with vomiting, intermittent abdominal pain, and currant jelly stools in children three months to three years old. This newborn presents with lethargy, hepatomegaly, and respiratory distress with respiratory alkalosis suggestive of a urea cycle disorder. The next best step is to check the ammonia level.
❌ Pyloric ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Pyloric ultrasonography can help confirm pyloric stenosis in patients presenting with projectile vomiting, poor weight gain, and a palpable, olive-shaped mass on abdominal examination. This newborn presents with lethargy, hepatomegaly, and respiratory distress with respiratory alkalosis suggestive of a urea cycle disorder. An ammonia level should be checked next.
✅ Serum ammonia level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum uric acid level:
Incorrect: Serum uric acid is useful in the evaluation of patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and glycogen storage disease type 1 (GSD I). Lesch-Nyhan syndrome may present with hypotonia, gout, and kidney stones, while GSD I typically presents with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly, but it is not associated with the respiratory alkalosis seen in this case. This newborn’s presentation is most consistent with a urea cycle disorder. An ammonia level is more diagnostic and should be ordered next.
❌ Urine drug screen:
Incorrect: A urine drug screen may help evaluate suspected neonatal abstinence syndrome, which can present with tremors, irritability, feeding difficulty, and vomiting. However, this infant’s respiratory alkalosis and progressive lethargy are more consistent with an inborn error of metabolism, making serum ammonia the more appropriate next test.

questions.text:
A 4-hour-old newborn delivered at 38 weeks’ gestation is being evaluated in the nursery for irritability and jitteriness. The mother had poorly controlled gestational diabetes during pregnancy. There is no history of maternal fever, rash, or drug use. Delivery was uneventful, with rupture of membranes for 6 hours. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Birth weight is 4,200 grams, and the newborn is breastfed. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 37/min, blood pressure is 72/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, no dysmorphic features are noted, and no rash is seen. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. A sacral dimple is seen on the back. Bedside glucose is 28 mg/dL. The neonate is breastfed three times, and repeated glucose measurements are 27, 25, and 26 mg/dL. Additional laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     24 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     75%    
 Leukocyte count     10,100/mm3    
 Platelet count     300,000/mm3    
 Serum glucose     30 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This newborn of a mother with diabetes is macrosomic (birth weight >4,000 grams) and presents with signs of hypoglycemia, including jitteriness and irritability, along with physical exam findings of caudal regression. Despite frequent feedings, the patient remains hypoglycemic, making intravenous (IV) dextrose infusion the most appropriate next step in management.        

Gestational diabetes increases the risk of neonatal and long-term complications. Poor maternal glycemic control leads to hyperinsulinism and neonatal hypoglycemia. Infants of diabetic mothers (IDMs) are often macrosomic, predisposing them to birth injuries. They may also have congenital anomalies, such as cardiac defects, neural tube defects, and neonatal small left colon syndrome. Postnatally, IDMs can present with hypoglycemic symptoms (e.g., jitteriness, irritability), respiratory distress, caudal regression signs, polycythemia, and hypocalcemia.    

In the case of neonatal hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinism, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized first. After stabilization, continuous vital sign monitoring and oxygen as needed should follow. In newborns with hypoglycemia that does not improve with feeding or supplementation, IV dextrose infusion should be started to maintain adequate blood glucose levels. Monitoring glucose levels is essential. IV glucagon can be considered if the dextrose infusion fails to maintain glucose levels. If hypoglycemia persists, further investigation is needed to evaluate for a possible endocrine pathology or inborn error of metabolism.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intubation and mechanical ventilation  :
Incorrect: Intubation and mechanical ventilation are essential in unstable patients with respiratory distress or failure. This patient is not experiencing tachypnea or increased work of breathing, and oxygen saturation is normal. Instead, the priority is addressing the patient's hypoglycemia. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) glucagon infusion :
Incorrect: IV glucagon is typically used when dextrose infusion is insufficient to maintain adequate blood glucose levels. This patient has not yet received a dextrose infusion, so glucagon is not the most appropriate next step.
✅ Intravenous (IV) dextrose infusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) normal saline bolus :
Incorrect: While a normal saline bolus may be needed in cases of hypotension or shock, this patient has a stable blood pressure. Instead, the priority is addressing the neonate’s hypoglycemia. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) antibiotics  :
Incorrect: IV antibiotics are typically started when there is concern for neonatal sepsis, which usually presents with risk factors for infection, temperature instability, or respiratory distress. This patient’s symptoms are more likely due to hypoglycemia, making intravenous dextrose the priority.

questions.text:
A 15-month-old boy is evaluated in the clinic for poor weight gain. Solid food was introduced at six months. His parents offer three meals a day but report he is a very picky eater. He eats fruits and breastfeeds although the patient’s mother is unsure of her supply. Parents report that the infant nurses on demand and drinks two cups of juice daily. The infant has adequate wet diapers each day, and two bowel movements daily. Stools are loose but without blood or mucus. There is no history of difficulty feeding, choking, or vomiting. Family history is non-contributory. The Infant was born at full term without complications at birth or during the pregnancy. Newborn screening tests were normal. Development has been appropriate for age. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 90/52 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Weight has dropped from the 45th percentile to the 10th percentile over the last four months. Height and head circumference are at the 25th percentile. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. No dysmorphic facial features are noted.  Pulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. A soft 1/6 flow murmur is appreciated at the left sternal border. An erythematous diaper rash is present. Complete blood count is shown below. Thyroid profile, liver and kidney functions are normal. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s symptoms?  
 
 Laboratory value      Result     
 Leukocyte count      8,500/mm³     
 Hemoglobin      9.2 g/dL     
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)      68 fl      
 Platelet count      320,000/mm³
questions.solution:
This infant presents with growth faltering as evidenced by the patient’s weight-for-age crossing 2 major percentile lines. The patient is a picky eater and drinks more juice than is recommended at 15 months. Although the patient frequently breastfeeds, the mother is unsure of her supply. The patient’s microcytic anemia and associated flow murmur support the history of inadequate intake, specifically iron intake. Inadequate caloric intake is the most likely etiology of his poor growth.

Growth faltering refers to the inability to gain or maintain adequate weight. The most common cause of growth faltering is inadequate intake, which can be due to insufficient supply or other reasons for inadequate food consumption, such as oral aversion. Inadequate intake in the neonatal period may reflect improper mixing of formula or difficulties with breastfeeding. At older ages, inadequate food supplies and excessive consumption of unbalanced sources of nutrition most often lead to inadequate intake.

Reviewing growth parameters on a standardized growth chart is the first step in the evaluation of growth faltering. If the patient’s weight-for-age or BMI is more than 2 standard deviations (<5th percentile) below the mean for age or if the weight-for-age has crossed 2 major percentile lines, growth faltering is diagnosed. To evaluate growth faltering secondary to inadequate caloric intake, a dietary assessment to examine calorie intake and feeding behaviors should be performed. History may reveal formula dilution, feeding massive quantities of juice or milk, an unbalanced diet that does not provide the necessary macronutrients for optimal growth, or food insecurity and resource instability. The evaluation for inadequate intake should also include assessing for vomiting, behavioral issues, mechanical feeding issues, and psychosocial issues.

Option Analysis

✅ Inadequate caloric intake :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Increased energy expenditure :
Incorrect: Increased energy expenditure can result from genetic conditions, immunodeficiencies, hyperthyroidism, or chronic cardiac, pulmonary, liver, or renal diseases, which are not noted in this infant. This infant’s heart murmur is an innocent murmur likely due to anemia. In this case, the limited food and high juice intake have most likely caused inadequate caloric intake leading to growth faltering. 
❌ Inborn errors of metabolism :
Incorrect: Patients with Inborn errors of metabolism (IEM) can present with vomiting, diarrhea, characteristic body odors, growth faltering, and labs showing hypoglycemia, ketonuria, and hyperammonemia, none of which are seen in this patient. In this case, the limited food and high juice intake have most likely caused inadequate caloric intake leading to growth faltering.
❌ Malabsorption :
Incorrect: Malabsorption in patients with cystic fibrosis or celiac disease commonly presents with diarrhea and steatorrhea along with growth faltering Although this patient has frequent loose stools, it is appropriate for his age and fruit-heavy diet. The findings in this case are more consistent with growth faltering secondary to inadequate caloric intake.  
❌ Feeding difficulties :
Incorrect: Feeding difficulties include poor latch, sucking, and swallowing and delayed acquisition of feeding skills. Although this patient has limited oral intake, it is due to pickiness and not due to mechanical feeding difficulties. This patient’s limited oral caloric intake is most likely because of his poor growth.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents with fever and cough for 4 days. She has a past medical history significant for recurrent episodes of pneumonia requiring several hospitalizations. Her parents report progressively worsening orthopnea requiring three pillows to sleep, along with dyspnea and cough over the past few months. They also report multiple falls over the last 6 months, and she now requires assistance with walking. She does not have associated diarrhea, vomiting, or skin rash. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 110/66 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 86% on room air. Physical examination reveals moist mucous membranes and no dysmorphic facial features or rashes. Bilateral weakness of the hip flexors is noted, and the patient is unable to walk without support. She has poor respiratory effort with decreased air entry in the right lower lobe. Cardiac and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Serum Chemistries
 Laboratory value Result
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 217 U/L
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 511 U/L
 Creatine kinase (CK) 750 U/L
 pH 7.36
 pCO2 50 mmHg
 pO2 58 mmHg
 HCO3 30 mEq/L
 Blood glucose 95 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This 6-year-old girl’s presentation is consistent with late-onset Pompe disease, as evidenced by her progressive muscle weakness, dyspnea, orthopnea, recurrent respiratory infections, and elevated creatine kinase (CK) and liver enzymes. The combination of her poor respiratory effort on examination, low oxygen saturation, and respiratory acidosis suggests significant respiratory muscle weakness. As a result, emergent intubation and mechanical ventilation are required to stabilize her airway and breathing.

Late-onset Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder (GSD) caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase, resulting in the accumulation of glycogen primarily in muscle tissue. It typically presents after one year of age, and sometimes during adolescence, with progressive muscle weakness in a limb-girdle distribution (e.g. hip flexors), delayed gross motor development, and respiratory compromise due to diaphragmatic weakness. Laboratory studies commonly show elevations in CK and liver enzymes along with a deficiency of acid alpha glucosidase. This presentation contrasts with the more severe form of Pompe disease (the “classic infantile onset” form) which, as the name suggests, presents within the first 3 months of life and includes hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in its phenotype.

In a patient presenting with an inborn error of metabolism like Pompe disease, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. In patients with signs of poor respiratory effort and low oxygen saturation, emergent intubation and mechanical ventilation is needed to maintain the airway and prevent respiratory failure. Once the patient is stabilized, continuous vital sign monitoring, supportive measures, and enzyme replacement therapy can be initiated.

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous dextrose bolus:
Incorrect: This patient has late-onset Pompe disease and is unstable with poor respiratory effort and low oxygen saturation. Their glucose level is normal, so a dextrose bolus will not be beneficial. The immediate priority is stabilization with emergency intubation and mechanical ventilation.
✅ Emergency intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetics consultation:
Incorrect: Although genetic testing can aid in confirming late-onset Pompe disease, this patient is unstable with poor respiratory effort and low oxygen saturation. The immediate priority is stabilization of their airway and breathing before proceeding with any consultations.
❌ Urgent echocardiography:
