Incorrect: An echocardiogram can help diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy seen in classic infantile-onset Pompe disease. However, given this patient's presentation of poor respiratory effort, muscle weakness, and laboratory findings suggestive of late-onset Pompe disease, the immediate priority is stabilization of their airway and breathing.
❌ Plasma exchange:
Incorrect: Plasma exchange is a treatment option for Guillain-Barré syndrome, which classically presents with rapidly progressive muscle weakness, paresthesias, and respiratory compromise after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. However, this patient's more protracted course — characterized by progressively worsening weakness, dyspnea, and orthopnea, as well as elevated CK and liver enzymes — is more consistent with late-onset Pompe disease. Additionally, this patient’s respiratory compromise makes stabilization of the airway and breathing the immediate priority.

questions.text:
A 16-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents with global developmental delays. She was born at full term to nonconsanguineous parents and has no significant family history. Her past medical history includes bilateral conductive hearing loss and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 99/56 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, notable facial dysmorphisms include frontal bossing, a broad-based nose, a large protruding tongue, and coarse facial features. She has a short neck with no skin rash. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is distended, and the liver is palpated at 2 cm below the costal margin. Both patient’s eyes have the findings seen in the image below. Which of the following best describes the fundoscopic examination findings expected in this patient?
 
Image Courtesy of Openi
questions.solution:
This 16-month-old infant has Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I, or MPS I). She presents with developmental delay with physical examination findings of coarse facial features, hepatomegaly, and corneal clouding. Fundoscopic examination in patients with Hurler syndrome is expected to reveal retinal degeneration.

Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive glycosaminoglycan lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused by a deficiency of the alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme, which results in glycosaminoglycan accumulation in the brain, eyes, tongue, liver, spleen, heart, spine, and lungs. Symptoms usually begin between 6 and 24 months of age and include progressive intellectual disability, skeletal abnormalities, and joint stiffness.

These patients often have recurrent respiratory infections, and some develop combined conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. Physical examination reveals coarse facial features such as macroglossia and macrocephaly, with prominent frontal bones, a large protruding tongue, and depressed nasal bridge. Ocular manifestations include corneal clouding, which can lead to blindness. Retinal degeneration and optic nerve compression can occur within the first year of life.

The diagnosis of Hurler syndrome is based on clinical examination and measurement of an alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme assay. A deficiency of this enzyme confirms the diagnosis.
Corneal clouding. Image courtesy of Openi 

Option Analysis

❌ Ectopia lentis:
Incorrect: Ectopia lentis is seen in patients with homocystinuria, which presents with intellectual disability, thromboembolism, and a Marfanoid appearance on exam. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.
❌ Optic atrophy:
Incorrect: Optic atrophy is seen in patients with Krabbe disease, which presents with feeding difficulties and seizures accompanied by rigidity, spasticity, and peripheral neuropathy on exam. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.
✅ Retinal degeneration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinal cherry-red spot:
Incorrect: A retinal cherry-red spot is seen in patients with Tay-Sachs disease, which presents with a gradual loss of milestones within the first months of life, an exaggerated startle response, macrocephaly, and hypotonia. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.
❌ Cataracts:
Incorrect: Cataracts may be seen in patients with congenital infections like rubella, which presents with microcephaly, a blueberry muffin rash, sensorineural hearing loss, and a patent ductus arteriosus. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Hurler syndrome, which is associated with retinal degeneration.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to feeding difficulties. His parents also report he is unable to support his head. There is no recent illness, fever, or skin rash. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, blood pressure is 94/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. His weight has fallen from the 25th to the 3rd percentile for age. No coarse facial features are seen on physical examination. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and spasticity. Cardiopulmonary and ophthalmologic exams are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity in peripheral blood leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 4-month-old infant presents with feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory studies demonstrate decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, which confirms the diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease.

In a patient presenting with a suspected inborn error of metabolism, the evaluation should include an assessment for progressive neurological deterioration. If present, the next step is to evaluate self-mutilating behavior and unusual odors. If both are absent, examine for organomegaly. Hepatosplenomegaly without coarse facial features, along with loss of early motor function, suggests Neimann-Pick disease. In contrast, the presence of both hepatosplenomegaly and coarse facial features, particularly when accompanied by corneal clouding, is more consistent with Hurler syndrome, whereas Hunter syndrome is not associated with corneal clouding.

Niemann-Pick disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of acid sphingomyelinase. This leads to the accumulation of sphingolipids throughout the body, resulting in tissue damage and organ dysfunction. Affected patients often present with feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. Regression of developmental milestones becomes noticeable by the age of one year. Physical examination typically reveals lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and spasticity or rigidity. Laboratory investigations can include a peripheral smear and lipid profile. Confirmation of the diagnosis is achieved by measuring acid sphingomyelinase activity in leukocytes and performing genetic analysis. A decreased acid sphingomyelinase level confirms the diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease, type A.

Option Analysis

❌ Hunter syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Hunter syndrome typically present with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, and a lack of corneal clouding (as compared to Hurler syndrome, which does have corneal clouding). In contrast, this patient presents with feeding difficulties, hepatosplenomegaly without coarse facial features, and decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, making Niemann-Pick disease the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Gaucher disease:
Incorrect: Patients with Gaucher disease present with fatigue, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, bruising, and short stature. This patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly and labs showing decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, making Niemann-Pick disease the most likely diagnosis.
✅ Niemann-Pick disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hurler syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Hurler syndrome typically present with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, and corneal clouding (as compared to Hunter syndrome, which does NOT have corneal clouding). This patient, however, presents with feeding difficulties, hepatosplenomegaly without coarse facial features, and decreased acid sphingomyelinase activity, making Niemann-Pick disease the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Late-onset Pompe disease:
Incorrect: Patients with late-onset Pompe disease present after one year of age with progressive muscle weakness and delayed gross motor development. However, they do not typically have hepatosplenomegaly, making Pompe disease unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 36-hour-old infant delivered at 38 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery is evaluated in the nursery for poor feeding, lethargy, and non-bloody, non-bilious emesis. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. The mother is group B Streptococcus negative. The infant is formula-fed. There is no temperature instability or rash. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 41/min, blood pressure is 70/42 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals lethargy, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. A complete blood count and urinalysis are normal, but transaminases are elevated. Bedside serum glucose level is 36 mg/dL. Blood and urine cultures and an ammonia level are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This early onset of symptoms in a newborn without clear signs of infection, such as risk factors or temperature instability, raises suspicion for an inborn error of metabolism (IEM). Hypoglycemia, a common complication of IEMs, should be treated with intravenous dextrose.

Inborn errors of metabolism (IEMs) can cause lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, and neurological decline in neonates. Affected infants often appear septic but lack fever, signs of infection, trauma, or congenital anomalies. History may reveal a positive newborn screen, a sibling with similar symptoms or unexplained death, or a family history of metabolic disease. Exam findings may include altered mental status, apnea or tachypnea, and hepatosplenomegaly.

Initial evaluation begins with an ABCDE assessment to determine clinical stability. Airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized first. Intravenous (IV) access should be obtained, and IV fluids initiated, if needed. Continuous vital sign monitoring and supplemental oxygen may be necessary. Because IEMs can mimic sepsis, empiric antibiotics should be considered. Prompt correction of hypoglycemia is essential.

Once stabilized, further evaluation includes a focused history and physical, arterial blood gas, complete blood count, metabolic panel, and urinalysis. Based on initial findings, additional tests such as serum ammonia and lactate can help identify specific metabolic disorders, including urea cycle or glycogen storage diseases.

Option Analysis

❌ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: This newborn presents with signs suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism. There is no evidence of respiratory distress or failure requiring intubation. However, the patient is hypoglycemic and requires supplemental glucose.
❌ Abdominal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasonography is used to evaluate bilious emesis or signs of obstruction. This newborn presents with non-bilious emesis and symptoms suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism. The patient’s glucose is 36 mg/dL and supplemental glucose is necessary.
✅ Intravenous dextrose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous saline bolus:
Incorrect: A saline bolus is indicated for hypotension or shock; however, this patient's blood pressure is within the normal range for age. The findings in this case are suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism, and the patient’s hypoglycemia requires treatment.
❌ Intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin:
Incorrect: Intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin are given to infants less than one month old when there is concern for sepsis or meningitis. This infant is afebrile and with a flat fontanelle. The findings in this case are most consistent with an inborn error of metabolism, and the patient’s hypoglycemia requires treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. Caregivers report that the child underwent a tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy yesterday. Postoperatively, there has been vomiting and minimal oral intake. There have been four minimally wet diapers and no stools in the past 24 hours. The child has a history of gross developmental delay, hypotonia, and poor weight gain. Height is at the 9th percentile and weight is at the 3rd percentile. Blood pressure is 88/42 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate is 38/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the child appears lethargic and is moaning while lying in a caregiver’s arms. Mucous membranes are dry, and capillary refill is 3 seconds. The posterior pharynx shows recent cauterization without active bleeding. No cardiac murmur is appreciated. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation, without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are diminished. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) score is 12. The child opens his eyes to verbal stimuli and withdraws to touch. Laboratory evaluation reveals an ammonia level of 100 µg/dL. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further questioning?
questions.solution:
This 2-year-old boy presents with altered mental status following repeated vomiting and decreased oral intake after a recent surgery. Medical history includes developmental delay, hypotonia, and poor weight gain. Physical examination is notable for tachycardia, tachypnea, lethargy, and a GCS score of 12. Laboratory testing reveals hyperammonemia. Taken together, these findings are consistent with an inborn error of metabolism (IEM), and a history of an abnormal newborn screen would be expected.       

The differential diagnosis for altered mental status in the pediatric population is broad and includes toxic ingestion, head trauma or intracranial lesion, infections, seizures, and metabolic disturbances. Because pediatric patients are often unable to provide a reliable history, input from caregivers is essential in establishing the history of present illness. Symptoms of altered mental status may include changes in consciousness, confusion, altered mood or behavior, or inconsolability. More severe cases can present with lethargy or coma.        

When evaluating a child with altered mental status, it is important to ask about potential exposures to medications, recreational substances, or household toxins. Head trauma should be considered, and associated signs such as periorbital ecchymosis or hemotympanum should be assessed. Fever, headache, photophobia, neck stiffness, and positive Kernig or Brudzinski signs raise concern for central nervous system infection. A postictal state or Todd paresis suggests recent seizure activity. In a patient with a suspected IEM, an abnormal newborn screen would be expected. Metabolic crises in these disorders are often triggered by physiologic stressors such as surgery or infection.       

Option Analysis

✅ History of abnormal newborn screen:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: Fever is a common finding in patients with an infectious process. However, this patient’s altered mental status in the setting of growth and developmental delays, poor oral intake, and elevated ammonia is most consistent with an inborn error of metabolism. 
❌ Recent head injury:
Incorrect: Head injuries can cause intracranial trauma and subsequent altered mental status. However, this patient’s altered mental status in the setting of growth and developmental delays, poor oral intake, and elevated ammonia is most consistent with an inborn error of metabolism. 
❌ Family member with gastroenteritis:
Incorrect: While gastroenteritis may lead to vomiting and dehydration, it would not explain this child's chronic hypotonia, growth delay, and elevated ammonia. These findings point to a likely inborn error of metabolism. 
❌ Unilateral weakness:
Incorrect: There are numerous causes of unilateral weakness, including Todd paresis following a seizure. However, this patient presents with hypotonia, growth and developmental delays, and an elevated ammonia level suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism (IEM). Although seizures and Todd paresis can occur in patients with an IEM, it is more likely that this patient had an abnormal newborn screen.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status in the setting of persistent non-bloody, nonbilious emesis for 48 hours. A caregiver reports the child has not been able to keep any food down and is only tolerating tiny amounts of water. The child has urinated once in the last 10 hours. There have been a few episodes of non-bloody diarrhea. There is no recent travel or known sick contacts. Weight is at the 15th percentile, and height is at the 30th percentile. Temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 96/57 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the child appears lethargic and is unable to answer questions appropriately. She is disoriented to place. Mucous membranes are dry, and capillary refill is 3 seconds. A soft flow murmur is noted. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 12. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 7-year-old girl presents with lethargy and confusion following 48 hours of persistent vomiting. The patient appears dehydrated with an abnormal GCS score. The clinical picture is most consistent with viral gastroenteritis, and the most appropriate next step in management is obtaining a bedside glucose level, as hypoglycemia is a common and readily reversible cause of altered mental status.        

After initial stabilization, the first diagnostic priority in evaluating altered mental status is always to check a bedside glucose level to assess for hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia. If glucose is normal, possible ingestion of medications or toxins should be considered. In such cases, urine and serum toxicology screening may be warranted. If there is concern for an intracranial process, computed tomography (CT) of the head is the preferred initial imaging modality.       

Infectious etiologies, including central nervous system or systemic infections, should also be considered. Evaluation may include a chest radiograph and urine, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid studies and cultures. Further testing may include arterial blood gas analysis, electroencephalogram (EEG), or serum ammonia and a comprehensive metabolic panel, depending on the suspected cause, such as hypoxemia, hypoventilation, seizures, or a metabolic disorder.   

Option Analysis

✅ Glucose level:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen:
Incorrect: Abdominal CT may help evaluate intra-abdominal pathology such as obstruction or appendicitis but is not the initial priority in a child with altered mental status. Given this presentation, a bedside glucose check should be performed first to assess for hypoglycemia, a common and reversible cause of lethargy and confusion. 
❌ Neurology consult:
Incorrect: Neurology consultation may prove useful when patients present with altered mental status due to a neurological condition, such as seizure disorder or an intracranial lesion. However, this patient’s fever, vomiting, and diarrhea are consistent with viral gastroenteritis. A bedside glucose level should be performed to assess for hypoglycemia. 
❌ Urine toxicology:
Incorrect: Ingestion of medications, recreational drugs, or household products can cause altered mental status. However, this child’s symptoms and limited oral intake place them at risk for hypoglycemia, which should be evaluated first with a bedside glucose check. 
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Central nervous system infection remains in the differential, but altered mental status with a history of vomiting and decreased oral intake warrants immediate evaluation for hypoglycemia. A bedside glucose test is essential before pursuing more invasive diagnostics such as lumbar puncture.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician to establish care after being adopted. The adoptive parents are not aware of significant past medical history or family history. Routine immunizations are up to date. The patient has no symptoms at this time. Height is 8<sup>th</sup> percentile, weight is less than 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile, and body-mass-index (BMI) is less than 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears proportional with normal upper-to-lower body segment ratios. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Bloodwork is obtained. Complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, inflammatory markers, tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A, and growth hormone levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of short stature in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 5-year-old patient presents to establish care after being adopted and is found to have short stature with a BMI below the 5th percentile. There is no known past medical history or family history. The patient has no symptoms at this time, and laboratory studies are normal. The most likely cause of this patient’s short stature is malnutrition or decreased caloric intake.

The initial evaluation of short stature requires a thorough history, physical examination, and evaluation of the growth chart. Important aspects of the history include birth history, dietary history, parental heights (in order to calculate mid-parental height), and family history of “later bloomers” or growth issues. The review of symptoms should be broad and assess for systemic symptoms and should especially highlight gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea). Physical examination should evaluate for dysmorphic features, pallor, murmur, goiter, skin findings, and lymphadenopathy.

One of the most important aspects of the physical examination in patients being assessed for short stature is an accurate height and weight measurement. Under age two, measurements should be plotted on a World Health Organization (WHO) growth chart. After age two, measurements should be plotted on a Centers for Disease Control (CDC) growth chart. There are special growth charts for specific situations, such as the Fenton growth chart for premature infants and growth charts specific to patients with Down syndrome and Noonan syndrome. Normal growth expectations are listed in the chart below. Heights that warrant further investigation are heights that don’t hit expected growth velocity, have crossed two major percentile lines, are more than two standard deviations from the mean, or are more than two inches from mid-parental height.
 

Option Analysis

✅ History of malnutrition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of skeletal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Skeletal dysplasia typically presents with disproportionate skeletal growth. This patient is proportional with short stature and a decreased weight-for-length ratio. A decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs is concerning for a history of malnutrition.
❌ History of prematurity:
Incorrect: Infants with prematurity have usually caught up growth-wise to their peers by two years of age. It would be uncommon for a 5-year-old to still have short stature and poor growth secondary to prematurity. A decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs is concerning for a history of malnutrition.
❌ Presence of a goiter:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can cause short stature, but the weight-for-length ratio is typically normal or increased. In addition, this patient has no symptoms that are concerning for hypothyroidism, such as fatigue, constipation, or cold intolerance. This patient has a decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs, which is concerning for a history of malnutrition.
❌ History of chronic abdominal pain:
Incorrect: Chronic abdominal pain due to celiac disease or other chronic illnesses, such as inflammatory bowel disease, can cause short stature with a decreased weight-for-length ratio. However, there would likely be lab abnormalities, whereas this patient’s labs are normal. A decreased weight-for-length ratio in the setting of normal labs is concerning for history of malnutrition.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a three-week history of fatigue and muscle cramps. His symptoms worsen with exercise, but if he rests after the warmup, he can usually rejoin the exercise with improvement in his symptoms. He also reports burgundy-colored urine after exercise. He has no associated fever, vomiting, diarrhea, skin rash, recent travel, or viral infections. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals mild swelling of his calf muscles. Laboratory studies reveal a markedly elevated creatine kinase (CK) level of 1,423 U/L. Which of the following additional lab findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
This 12-year-old boy has myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease). He presents with fatigue, muscle cramps, and the classic “second wind” phenomenon. Laboratory studies reveal a markedly elevated CK level. An elevated urine myoglobin level is expected.

McArdle disease is an autosomal recessive glycogen storage disorder affecting the skeletal muscle due to deficiency (or absence) of the myophosphorylase enzyme, resulting in glycogen accumulation in tissues. It typically presents in late childhood with fatigue, exercise intolerance (due to cramps and myalgia), and burgundy-colored urine after exercise (due to myoglobinuria). Physical examination may reveal muscle swelling. The "second wind"phenomenon is pathognomonic for McArdle disease, in which rapid relief of fatigue and myalgia occurs after about 10 minutes of exercise because of increased blood flow, improved free fatty acid delivery, and increased liver glucose utilization.

Diagnosis is confirmed by obtaining labs and muscle biopsy. CK and urine myoglobin are usually elevated, and muscle biopsy demonstrates elevated glycogen and decreased muscle phosphorylase activity. The forearm exercise test (comparing lactate and ammonia before and after one minute of rhythmic exercise) shows no elevation of blood lactate levels.

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased sphingomyelinase levels:
Incorrect: Decreased sphingomyelinase levels are seen in Neiman-Pick disease, which typically presents with organomegaly, feeding difficulties, and loss of early motor skills. The findings in this patient are more consistent with myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease), and elevated urine myoglobin is expected.
❌ Elevated uric acid level:
Incorrect: Elevated uric acid is seen in Lesch-Nyhan disease, characterized by progressive neurologic deterioration and self-mutilating behavior. The findings in this patient are more consistent with myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease), and elevated urine myoglobin is expected.
✅ Elevated urine myoglobin level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elevated homocysteine level:
Incorrect: An elevated homocysteine level is seen in homocystinuria, which typically presents with ectopia lentis, intellectual disability, thromboembolism, and a Marfanoid appearance. The findings in this patient are more consistent with myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease), and elevated urine myoglobin is expected.
❌ Elevated phenylalanine level:
Incorrect: An elevated phenylalanine level is seen in phenylketonuria, characterized by a musty or mousy odor, progressive intellectual disability, seizures, and lighter skin pigmentation. The findings in this patient are more consistent with myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease), and elevated urine myoglobin is expected.

questions.text: A 6-day-old boy is admitted to the hospital with fever, difficulty feeding, and jaundice. The infant was delivered via spontaneous vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. The infant is breastfed and has appropriate wet diapers and bowel movements. Family history is non-contributory. Newborn screen results are pending. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 80/45 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam, the infant is hypotonic, and hepatomegaly is noted. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Cardiopulmonary exam is normal. Maternal and infant blood types are both A positive. Laboratory studies reveal direct hyperbilirubinemia and elevated transaminase levels. Blood culture is positive for Escherichia coli. Which of the following physical exam findings is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This newborn exhibits signs and symptoms consistent with galactosemia, including feeding difficulties, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory findings reveal direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevated transaminase levels, and a positive blood culture for Escherichia coli. Physical examination may reveal cataracts, a recognized clinical feature of galactosemia.

Inborn errors of metabolism (IEMs) typically present during infancy with poor feeding, vomiting, and irritability. The history may include a positive newborn screen, a sibling with an unexplained death or similar symptoms, or a relevant family history. On examination, findings may include altered mental status, hypotonia, abnormal respiratory patterns such as rapid deep breathing or apnea, and hepatosplenomegaly.

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). Following ingestion of lactose or galactose-containing products (e.g., breast milk, standard formula), galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in tissues, particularly the liver and eyes. Affected infants may present with lethargy, feeding intolerance, hepatic dysfunction, and sepsis due to E. coli, especially before newborn screening results are available. Long-term complications include developmental and learning delays. On physical exam, hepatomegaly, persistent jaundice, and cataracts may be present. The diagnosis is supported by the presence of non-glucose-reducing substances in the urine and absent GALT activity. Management includes immediate discontinuation of lactose-containing feeds and initiation of a soy-based formula.

Option Analysis

✅ Cataracts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hearing loss:
Incorrect: Sensorineural hearing loss can occur in congenital rubella syndrome, which may also present with cataracts, a patent ductus arteriosus, and a blueberry muffin rash. This patient’s presentation is consistent with galactosemia, which is associated with cataracts, but not hearing loss.
❌ Sweet odor of the sweat:
Incorrect: A sweet odor to the sweat is characteristic of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), which typically presents with encephalopathy, vomiting, hypertonia, and opisthotonus. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with galactosemia, which is associated with cataracts.
❌ Thin vermillion border:
Incorrect: A thin vermilion border can be seen in patients with primary pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency (PDCD), a mitochondrial disorder of carbohydrate oxidation that presents with developmental delays, hypotonia, and seizures. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with galactosemia, which is associated with cataracts.
❌ Xanthomas:
Incorrect: Xanthomas are seen with glycogen storage disease type 1, in addition to doll-like facies, hepatosplenomegaly, and hypotonia. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with galactosemia, which is associated with cataracts.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to worsening headaches and altered mental status. The patient is unable to provide a thorough history. A medical record review reveals that the patient was diagnosed with HIV, has been inconsistent in obtaining treatment, and his CD4+ count was 42/mm3 a month ago. Temperature is 39.5°C (103°F), blood pressure is 127/73 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. The patient is oriented to self on physical examination, but not place or time. Blood cultures are obtained and reveal the findings below. The patient is started on a medication that inhibits fungal 14-alpha-demethylase. Long-term administration of this medication may cause which of the following side effects?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has altered mental status, headaches, and fever in the setting of a low CD4+ cell count. Blood samples reveal the presence of an organism with pseudohyphae and spores, making invasive candidiasis the most likely diagnosis. Azoles are a class of antifungals that work by inhibiting fungal 14-alpha demethylase and can be used to treat invasive candidiasis.  

Topical azoles are generally safe but may lead to skin irritation. However, azoles can also cause several side effects. If used systematically, azoles can cause hepatotoxicity. This medication class also inhibits human cytochrome p450, leading to the accumulation of medications metabolized by these enzymes (e.g., warfarin, phenytoin).    

Moreover, azoles, in particular ketoconazole, can inhibit the synthesis of androgens in the adrenal gland and testes, leading to gynecomastia and infertility. In rare cases, when patients are on high doses of ketoconazole for a prolonged duration, it can suppress glucocorticoid production by the adrenal glands and cause adrenal insufficiency. Finally, voriconazole may cause visual disturbances.   



Option Analysis

❌ Renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent that can treat systemic fungal infections, including Candida bacteremia. The medication can cause type I renal tubular acidosis as a side effect. However, amphotericin B does not work by inhibiting 14-alpha-demethylase activity.   
❌ Hirsutism:
Incorrect: Azoles, in particular ketoconazole, may inhibit androgen synthesis and lead to gynecomastia and infertility. Azoles do not usually manifest with clinical findings of hyperandrogenism.  
❌ Pseudomembranous colitis:
Incorrect: Several antibiotics, including clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, and cephalosporins, can predispose patients to Clostridium difficile infection and subsequent pseudomembranous colitis. However, these agents would not be effective in treating candidemia.  
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Uncommonly, prolonged use of azole drugs can cause adrenal insufficiency as a side effect, which would lead to hypoglycemia, not hyperglycemia.  
✅ Adrenal insufficiency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man is diagnosed with Gram-positive bacteremia and started on Antibiotic X. The drug is administered intravenously and requires a plasma concentration of at least 20 mg/L to achieve therapeutic effects. Additional information regarding Antibiotic X’s pharmacokinetics is listed below. Unfortunately, Antibiotic X can lead to severe side effects. As a result, the ordering physician wants to administer the lowest possible dose. Suppose the patient's body weight is 75 kg. Which of the following would be the smallest loading dose of Antibiotic X that can achieve therapeutic levels?  

Pharmacokinetic Parameter
Value
Volume of distribution  
0.4 L/kg  
Dosing interval  
6 hours  
Bioavailability*  
100%  
Elimination rate  
2.6 L/h  
*For intravenous administration
questions.solution:
This patient has Gram-positive bacteremia and is started on Antibiotic X, administered via an intermittent dosing regimen. In other words, the medication is administered at regular time intervals. In emergency cases, a loading dose (a large dose given at the beginning of treatment) can be administered to help the medication rapidly achieve target concentrations. Maintenance doses, given at scheduled intervals, can be subsequently administered to help keep the drug level at a steady state. The loading dose can be calculated via the equation above.

The first step in determining the loading dose of Antibiotic X for this patient would be to calculate the patient’s volume of distribution, which equals 0.4 L/kg*75 kg, or 30 L. Afterwards, the loading dose can be calculated as follows:

   Loading dose = (20 mg/L * 30 L) / 100% = 600 mg / 1 = 600 mg

Therefore, a loading dose of at least 600 mg would be required for Antibiotic X to reach therapeutic levels in this patient.
 

Option Analysis

❌ 300 mg:
Incorrect: This patient has a volume of distribution of 30 L (0.4 L/kg*75 kg). Given Antibiotic X is intravenously administered and has a bioavailability of 100%, a loading dose of 600 mg would be necessary to achieve therapeutic levels. In contrast, a 300 mg loading dose would be insufficient.  
❌ 450 mg:
Incorrect: This patient has a volume of distribution of 30 L (0.4 L/kg*75 kg). Given Antibiotic X is intravenously administered and has a bioavailability of 100%, a loading dose of 600 mg would be necessary to achieve therapeutic levels. In contrast, a 450 mg loading dose would be insufficient.  
✅ 600 mg:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 850 mg:
Incorrect: A minimum loading dose of 600 mg is required for Antibiotic X to reach therapeutic levels in this patient. A loading dose of 850 mg would be excessive and increase the risk of side effects.  
❌ 1500 mg:
Incorrect: A minimum loading dose of 600 mg is required for Antibiotic X to reach therapeutic levels in this patient. A loading dose of 1500 mg would be excessive and increase the risk of side effects.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for tuberculosis screening before starting a new job as a part-time nurse at a prison. He currently has a right sided headache with photophobia, a cough that he says is no different from his chronic cough, and low back pain. Past medical history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, coronary artery disease, and migraines. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, fluticasone-salmeterol, sumatriptan and verapamil. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 86/min, blood pressure is 128/83 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has a dry cough. He is alert and oriented and there are no focal neurological deficits. There is no nuchal rigidity. Cardiac auscultation is within normal limits. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation. There is tenderness to palpation along the lumbar paravertebral musculature but none along the spinous processes. A serum interferon gamma release assay is positive. Chest radiograph is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who is starting a job as a health care worker in a prison was scheduled to have screening for tuberculosis given that his occupation puts him at high risk for tuberculosis (TB) exposure. The interferon-gamma release assay is positive, but he has no new pulmonary or other symptoms of tuberculosis infection, and his chest x-ray is normal; therefore, he has tuberculosis infection or latent TB.

Tuberculosis is an infection due to the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It frequently results in pulmonary disease (pulmonary tuberculosis) but can cause an asymptomatic state called latent tuberculosis. It can also cause systemic infection that can lead to extrapulmonary tuberculosis.

Screening for tuberculosis infection should be performed in certain populations who are at high risk of developing tuberculosis and therefore would benefit from treatment. This includes patients who are at risk of developing a new infection (close contact with people with untreated TB and healthcare workers who may have occupational exposures). Patients at high risk of reactivation or TB disease progression, like patients with underlying immunosuppression and patients at moderate or slightly increased risk of reactivation who live in areas where TB is prevalent, should also be screened. For patients at risk,  interferon-gamma release assay or tuberculin skin test should be performed to confirm the presence of tuberculosis. Chest radiography should be performed if either test is positive, in order to differentiate between pulmonary tuberculosis and latent tuberculosis. Patients with latent tuberculosis generally do not have any significant physical exam or chest x-ray findings.  

Option Analysis

✅ Latent tuberculosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pulmonary tuberculosis:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest radiograph shows no evidence of active pulmonary tuberculosis, and he has no new pulmonary symptoms. He has a chronic cough secondary to COPD.  
❌ Spinal tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Spinal tuberculosis may present with back pain, spasms, tenderness to palpation along the spinous processes, and possibly neurologic deficits. This patient may have back pain and spasms, but there is no tenderness and no neurologic deficits.  
❌ Tuberculous pericarditis:
Incorrect: Patients with tuberculous pericarditis may present with sharp chest pain, shortness of breath, signs such as jugular venous distention, and a pericardial friction rub. This patient does not have these symptoms, and he has no cardiac abnormalities on exam.  
❌ Tuberculous meningitis:
Incorrect: Patients with tuberculous meningitis may present with headache and photophobia. However, they will generally have nuchal rigidity and neurologic deficits which this patient does not have. He is likely experiencing a migraine headache.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic due to recurrent fevers and a painful lump in her right axilla for the past three weeks. She recently went on a camping trip to a lake in New Hampshire. She works in a daycare, and many children have been sick recently. She has a cat and a dog at home. She remembers having a red papule on the upper arm about a week before when the axillary lump appeared. Temperature is 38.3 °C (100.9 °F), blood pressure is 112/72 mmHg, heart rate is 106 beats/minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths/minute, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On examination, several tender, enlarged lymph nodes are palpable in the right axillary region. The rest of the physical examination is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with tender, regional lymphadenopathy that has progressed over the course of several weeks, with a erythematous papule preceding the lymphadenopathy, and a cat living at home. Cat scratch disease (i.e. Bartonella henselae infection) best fits the characteristics and time course of the described findings.

Lymphadenopathy may be localized or generalized. Localized lymphadenopathy often occurs in the vicinity of an infection, disease, or site of inoculation, and will follow the typical lymphatic drainage for that region. Examples include pharyngitis, vaccinations, cat scratch disease, and some malignancies. Generalized lymphadenopathy is defined as lymphadenopathy that is present in 2 or more non-contiguous areas. Generalized lymphadenopathy can occur with disseminated infections, systemic inflammatory diseases, and some malignancies.

In addition to determining if lymphadenopathy is localized or generalized, characteristics of the lymph nodes themselves should be considered when making a diagnosis. Acute inflammatory or infectious etiologies tend to result in rapid enlargement of lymph nodes, which will be tender to palpation. Lymphadenopathy associated with most acute infections tends to have a rapid onset and short duration. Lymph nodes that have been present for less than two weeks often have a benign cause. Other, more persistent or disseminated infections and conditions will have a longer progression and duration. Lymph nodes tend to be firm and rubbery in lymphoma, while infiltrative processes (e.g., metastatic disease) or fibrosis can make the nodes feel hard.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cat scratch disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma presents with painless, gradually enlarging lymphadenopathy, accompanied by systemic symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss. This patient’s history, signs and symptoms, along with the physical examination findings, do not fit this diagnosis.  
❌ Sarcoidosis:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis can present with lymphadenopathy, pulmonary manifestations, and systemic symptoms, like fever and weight loss. Lymphadenopathy in sarcoidosis is typically bilateral, symmetric, and nontender. This patient’s history, signs and symptoms, along with the physical examination findings, do not fit this diagnosis.  
❌ Viral pharyngitis:
Incorrect: Viral pharyngitis often presents with sore throat, fever, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Given the patient's occupation in a daycare, a viral infection could be a consideration. However, the 3-week course of symptoms and specific location of this patient’s lymphadenopathy make this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Acute otitis externa:
Incorrect: Acute otitis externa can present with ear pain, tenderness, and sometimes regional lymphadenopathy. The patient's recent camping trip and potential exposure to water bodies could make this diagnosis a possibility. However, lymphadenopathy would be more localized to the regions draining the ear and symptoms of ear pain would be expected, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status and fevers. Her partner states that over the past several days, the patient was complaining of shortness of breath and a cough that has been productive of thick, yellow sputum. Her partner also states she has had temperatures as high as 102.3°F (38.9°C). She has a past medical history of atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and COPD. Her medications include apixaban, metformin, lisinopril, and daily formoterol. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 96/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. The patient is somnolent but arousable and is able to answer basic orientation questions. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals crackles at the left lung base. There is dullness to percussion. No wheezes are heard. Heart rate is tachycardic and irregularly irregular. The patient is placed on 2 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula with improvement of oxygen saturation to 95%. Chest X-ray reveals a consolidation of the left lower lobe. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Oral antibiotics and follow-up in 24 hours
Immediate bronchoscopy to identify the pathogen
CT scan of the chest to further characterize the consolidation

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of severe sepsis (altered mental status, hypotension, tachycardia) most likely secondary to an underlying pneumonia. The patient requires immediate stabilization with intravenous fluids and the initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Pneumonia, particularly in elderly patients with comorbid conditions (such as COPD, diabetes mellitus, and cardiovascular disease) can rapidly progress to sepsis or septic shock, conditions characterized by systemic inflammation, tissue perfusion abnormalities, and organ dysfunction.

Intravenous fluids are essential for restoring adequate circulation and addressing hypotension, a common manifestation of sepsis due to vasodilation and increased vascular permeability. Fluid resuscitation aims to improve tissue perfusion and oxygenation, which can prevent the progression of sepsis to severe sepsis or septic shock. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated to cover the likely pathogens causing pneumonia (e.g. Streptococcus pneumoniae) while awaiting specific identification of the causative agent. Delayed antibiotic therapy in the context of sepsis is associated with significantly higher mortality rates. The choice of antibiotics should be guided by local antibiogram data, the patient's allergy history, and potential drug interactions (especially considering this patient’s current medication regimen, including apixaban, which could be affected by certain antibiotics).   

Option Analysis

❌ Oral antibiotics and follow-up in 24 hours:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of severe infection and sepsis, indicated by altered mental status and hypotension. Discharging a patient in this condition would be inappropriate. Broad spectrum intravenous antibiotics should be started. 
❌ Immediate bronchoscopy to identify the pathogen:
Incorrect: While identifying the pathogen is important, the immediate next step should focus on stabilizing the patient and starting empirical treatment for suspected pneumonia. Bronchoscopy can be considered later if the patient’s clinical status continues to deteriorate after initial therapies. 
❌ CT scan of the chest to further characterize the consolidation:
Incorrect: A CT scan may provide additional details about the consolidation, but it is not the immediate next step in the management of a patient with signs of severe infection and sepsis. Initial management should focus on stabilization with broad spectrum empirical antibiotics.  
✅ Intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: Although the patient initially presented with hypoxia, her oxygen saturation improved with supplemental oxygen; therefore, there is no indication for mechanical ventilation at this moment. The decision for mechanical ventilation would depend on further clinical deterioration or inability to maintain adequate oxygenation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the primary care physician due to severe fatigue. The patient has had a mild sore throat, myalgias, and severe fatigue for the past two weeks. She reports that rest and ibuprofen have not alleviated the symptoms. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medication daily. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational substances. Temperature is 38.6 ºC (101.5 ºF), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 106/67 mmHg. A thorough physical examination is performed. Oropharyngeal exam shows swollen edematous tonsils bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Serum testing shows a positive heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This 17-year-old girl presents with two weeks of myalgias, sore throat, and severe fatigue with positive heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM testing confirming a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM). Splenomegaly is often seen in patients with infectious mononucleosis (IM) due to lymphocytic infiltration of the spleen.    

IM is a viral syndrome caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which spreads through saliva or respiratory secretions (often referred to as the “kissing disease” in young patients). After the virus enters the mouth, it infects oropharyngeal epithelial cells leading to sore throat, and B cells, which contribute to the presence of atypical lymphocytes seen on a peripheral smear.    

Patients generally present with fever, fatigue, myalgias, and sore throat. On physical examination, patients may have erythematous swollen tonsils, tonsillar exudates, and palatal petechiae. Posterior cervical chain lymphadenopathy is frequently present as well. In some cases, splenomegaly can be seen. Patients with splenomegaly should avoid strenuous exercise and contact sports for at least three weeks, due to the risk of splenic rupture.  



Option Analysis

✅ Splenomegaly :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Infraclavicular lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Infraclavicular lymphadenopathy is not specifically associated with infectious mononucleosis. Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, however, is a common feature. 
❌ Hepatomegaly:
Incorrect: Hepatomegaly can occur in patients with infectious mononucleosis in rare cases; however, splenomegaly is much more common, in up to 50% of infectious mononucleosis cases. 
❌ Arthritis:
Incorrect: While myalgias can be a prominent symptom of infectious mononucleosis, arthritis would not be an expected finding. Acute arthritis would suggest a different process (e.g., parvovirus B19). 
❌ Productive cough:
Incorrect: A dry cough can rarely be seen in patients with infectious mononucleosis due to pharyngeal irritation; however, a productive cough would not be expected.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of fever, body aches, headache, and chills since returning to the United States two days ago. The patient is a medical student who is returning from Ecuador where she was pursuing a medical Spanish elective in the Amazon rainforest. The patient ate the local food and drank water from a tap. She was bitten by multiple mosquitos during her elective. The patient has no past medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 113/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. No rash is present. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination are within normal limits. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient who recently returned from a tropical region presents with fever, headache, myalgias, and chills. The peripheral blood smear reveals visible plasmodium parasites, confirming the diagnosis of malaria. Malaria is the most common life-threatening tropical disease associated with fever in returned travelers, particularly from regions such as South America, Africa, and Asia.

All patients returning from travel with a fever should be presumed to have an endemic illness from the country where they traveled. The differential diagnosis is then formulated based on travel history, symptoms, and physical exam features, including the presence or absence of a rash. Further confirmatory testing may then be necessary to make a diagnosis, which can be achieved via a variety of modalities, including nucleic amplification testing, serology, or stool/blood culture. Malaria can be diagnosed by microscopic analysis of the blood showing visible plasmodium parasites or by using parasite-specific NAAT of the serum.

Option Analysis

✅ Malaria :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ African sleeping sickness:
Incorrect: Patients with African sleeping sickness may have fever and headaches; however, microscopic analysis of blood will show elongated slender trypanosomes. The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.
❌ Rocky Mountain spotted fever:
Incorrect: Patients with Rocky Mountain spotted fever typically present with a diffuse petechial rash, and diagnosis can be made with serologic testing. The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.
❌ Japanese encephalitis:
Incorrect: Japanese encephalitis typically presents with neurologic findings and a history of recent travel to Asia. Diagnosis is made with the presence of serum or cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) IgM antibodies. The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.
❌ Yellow fever:
Incorrect: Patients with yellow fever typically present with jaundice and bleeding. The disease is caused by a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes or Haemagogus mosquitoes. It is diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT). The peripheral smear in this case shows plasmodium falciparum parasites consistent with malaria.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a fever, body aches, and chills. The patient was recently backpacking through South America and returned to the United States two days ago. The fever has been present for one day. The patient was camping near the tropical Pacific coastline, and he was bitten by several mosquitos. He reports associated nausea and diarrhea. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 17/min, blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued with dry mucous membranes. No rash is present. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination are within normal limits. Which of the following is most helpful for narrowing down the differential diagnosis in this returned traveler who has a fever?

choices.text: Presence or absence of a rash, and its appearance if present
Presence or absence of gastrointestinal symptoms

questions.solution:
This patient recently traveled to a tropical region and presents with fever and associated body aches, chills, nausea, and diarrhea. The differential for fever in a returned traveler is broad, and one of the key findings that can help narrow down the differential diagnosis is the presence or absence of a rash and its characteristics, if present.

All patients returning from international travel with a fever should be presumed to have an endemic illness from that country and should have a targeted history and physical examination. Key historical features include the presence or absence of a rash, location of travel, exposure to insect bites, consumption of contaminated food/water, as well as presence of associated constitutional symptoms like myalgias, chills, and headaches, and gastrointestinal symptoms, like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Physical examination should take note of signs of dehydration like dry mucous membranes and tachycardia. The presence of a rash and the characteristics of the rash (i.e. maculopapular vs petechial), if one is present, can be very helpful for narrowing down the differential diagnosis. Diseases to consider in returning travelers with a fever and rash include African sleeping sickness, Dengue, Zika, Ebola, Chikungunya, typhoid, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Diseases where a rash is not present include traveler’s diarrhea, Japanese encephalitis, yellow fever, and malaria.

Option Analysis

✅ Presence or absence of a rash, and its appearance if present:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Duration of the fever:
Incorrect: The duration of fever does not assist in narrowing the differential. The duration of fever may vary in certain diseases and many diseases can have the same length of fever.
❌ Height of the fever:
Incorrect: The height of the fever is not an indication of the specific infection in returning travelers with fever.
❌ History of insect bites:
Incorrect: Insects can be vectors for many different diseases; therefore, this may not be as helpful for narrowing down the differential but may aid in making a final diagnosis.
❌ Presence or absence of gastrointestinal symptoms:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, can be seen with multiple different diseases that can be the cause of fever in a returned traveler.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a new rash on her left thigh. The rash developed three days ago and has been slowly enlarging since then. She recently went camping in the Appalachian Mountains and removed a tick from the area about five days ago. The patient has been experiencing fatigue, a mild fever, and myalgia on review of systems. She is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Physical examination is notable for a large bright red targetoid lesion on the left thigh. She is prescribed an oral antibiotic to take for three weeks. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the first-line antibiotic treatment for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors
Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome
Binding to phospholipids on the bacterial cell membrane

questions.solution:
After hiking in the Appalachian mountains, this patient presents with a targetoid rash and flu-like symptoms. This infection is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through the Ixodes scapularis tick. Infection occurs in the New England and mid-Atlantic regions of the United States.

Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic antibiotics. The first-line treatment for Lyme disease is doxycycline, a tetracycline antibiotic that inhibits the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, thereby preventing the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA. Other examples of tetracyclines include minocycline and tigecycline.

Apart from treating Lyme disease, tetracyclines are also used to treat infections caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Rickettsia rickettsii, Chlamydia species, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

The most common adverse effects include gastrointestinal distress, photosensitivity, tinnitus, and hepatotoxicity. Tetracyclines can also accumulate in the teeth and bones, causing discoloration of the teeth and inhibition of bone growth. As a result, they are contraindicated in pregnancy, women who are breastfeeding, and children less than 8-years-old. Finally, they should not be taken with milk, antacids, or iron-containing preparations as they contain divalent cations (calcium, magnesium) that can inhibit the absorption of tetracyclines in the gut.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones. They are a class of bactericidal antibiotics that are most effective against Gram-negative bacteria in the genitourinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and some Gram-positive bacteria. However, fluoroquinolones are not the first-line antibiotic for treating Lyme disease.  
❌ Formation of toxic free radicals:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of metronidazole. It is used to treat infections caused by Giardia lamblia, Entamoeba histolytica, Gardnerella vaginalis, Bacteroides species, and Clostridium difficile. However, fluoroquinolones are not used in the treatment of Lyme disease.  
❌ Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Vancomycin is used to treat multidrug-resistant severe infections with Gram-positive bacteria, but not Lyme disease caused by Boreilla burdefori.  
✅ Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Binding to phospholipids on the bacterial cell membrane:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of polymyxins. They disrupt cell membrane integrity, causing leakage of cellular components and cell death. They are used as salvage therapy in multidrug-resistant Gram-positive infections. They are not used in the treatment of Lyme disease.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a high fever, chills, headache, myalgias, and a diffuse red rash. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.5 °F), blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, heart rate is 122/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Mucous membranes appear dry, and capillary refill time is delayed. Skin exam is significant for a diffuse macular erythematous rash. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. A retained tampon is found on pelvic exam with dried blood. Laboratory findings are listed below. Blood cultures are drawn, and the patient is started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. Blood pressure remains 78/42 after initial fluid resuscitation. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory test  
Result
White blood cell count
18,000 /µL  
Platelet count  
70,000 /µL  
Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL  
AST
80 U/L  
ALT
95 U/L
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome (fever, hypotension, tachycardia, diffuse macular erythroderma, multisystem dysfunction, retained tampon). Despite appropriate fluid resuscitation, her blood pressure remains low. In this case, a vasopressor such as norepinephrine should be initiated to maintain perfusion.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a serious multisystem disease where toxin production by bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes) causes an exaggerated inflammatory response. This results in shock and organ damage. TSS may develop from skin and soft tissue infections or contaminated foreign bodies.

When TSS is suspected, an ABCDE assessment is critical as these patients are most often hemodynamically unstable. IV access should be obtained promptly, and continuous vital sign monitoring should be initiated. Patients usually need aggressive IV fluid resuscitation and vasopressors. Patients with respiratory compromise may require intubation. In addition, laboratory studies and blood cultures should be obtained. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are typically initiated, including antibiotics targeting toxin production (e.g. clindamycin, linezolid).  

Option Analysis

✅ Start norepinephrine infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pursue endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically unstable due to toxic shock syndrome. However, she does not have evidence of respiratory compromise or failure. Thus, intubation and mechanical ventilation is not warranted.  
❌ Order IV methylprednisolone and diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Antihistamines and corticosteroids would be indicated for a severe allergic reaction. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with toxic shock syndrome from an infection.  
❌ Continue IV fluid hydration:
Incorrect: While continued IV fluids may be given, this patient’s hypotension has not improved with fluid resuscitation. Therefore, a vasopressor is warranted.  
❌ Order platelet transfusion:
Incorrect: While thrombocytopenia is present, there is no evidence of active bleeding that would necessitate a platelet transfusion.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a high fever, generalized body aches, nausea, and headache. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 80/42 mmHg, heart rate is 128/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. She appears acutely ill with warm, flushed skin and the presence of a diffuse macular erythematous rash that is similar to a sunburn that is covering most of her body, including the trunk, palms, and soles. There is no nuchal rigidity, and Nikolsky sign is negative. Which of the following additional factors is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Recent antibiotic use for a urinary tract infection
Current housing in a dormitory setting

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms and physical exam findings that are consistent with toxic shock syndrome (e.g. hemodynamic instability, diffuse erythroderma). Risk factors for the disease should be assessed, including recent use of high-absorbency tampons.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a serious multisystem disease where toxin production by bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes) causes an exaggerated inflammatory response. This results in shock and organ damage. TSS may develop from skin and soft tissue infections or contaminated foreign bodies. Risk factors should be assessed upon presentation, including recent procedures or surgeries (including childbirth), cuts or abrasions, nasal packing, and use of high-absorbency tampons.

Patients with TSS often present with nonspecific symptoms, such as fever, myalgias, and headache. Gastrointestinal symptoms may also be present, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Physical examination findings include fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. Cutaneous manifestations, such as a macular erythroderma, can be seen. Macular erythroderma is a diffuse erythematous rash covering most of the body that may involve the palms and soles, and desquamation may occur later after initial onset.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recent use of high-absorbency tampons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recent antibiotic use for a urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Steven-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis secondary to medications can present similarly; however, the rash typically spares the palms and soles. Additionally, Nikolsky sign would be expected to be positive.  
❌ Current housing in a dormitory setting:
Incorrect: While meningococcal disease would be in the differential diagnosis, her lack of nuchal rigidity makes meningitis less likely.  
❌ Recent initiation of oral contraceptives:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Oral contraceptives are not associated with this condition.  
❌ Recent hiking trip to Missouri:
Incorrect: Tick-borne illnesses, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, can present with an erythematous rash. However, the rash of RMSF is typically described as a blanching, maculopapular or petechial rash that starts as small pink macules on the extremities that then can involve the trunk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting. He was in the emergency department a few days ago for a bloody nose. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 74/40 mmHg, heart rate is 130/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, he appears acutely ill with bilateral nasal packing still in place. His skin examination reveals a diffuse, erythematous macular rash. Which of the following laboratory findings would be consistent with the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms, examination, and history are consistent with toxic shock syndrome, likely as a result of nasal packing for epistaxis. Laboratory studies will generally demonstrate evidence of multiorgan dysfunction, such as an elevated creatinine level.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a serious multisystem disease where toxin production by bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes) causes an exaggerated inflammatory response. Most cases of TSS are due to methicillin-susceptible S. aureus (MSSA), though cases secondary to MRSA have been emerging. Streptococcal TSS occurs most frequently in the setting of infection due to group A Streptococcus. Isolation of group A streptococcus from blood or tissue culture is required for diagnosis of streptococcal TSS. Staph TSS does not require positive cultures for diagnosis as they are often negative.

Laboratory studies in TSS can show a multitude of findings. Leukocytosis with left shift, anemia, and/or thrombocytopenia may be seen on a complete blood cell count. Metabolic panels may show an elevated BUN and creatinine, elevated liver enzymes, low albumin, and creatine phosphokinase (if myositis or necrotizing fasciitis is present). Lactic acidosis, DIC, and electrolyte abnormalities may also be present. All of these are influenced by the underlying inflammation, hypoperfusion, and multiorgan dysfunction that results from the disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated serum creatinine level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated eosinophils:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Laboratory studies will generally demonstrate elevated neutrophils and bands, not eosinophils.  
❌ Normal lactic acid:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. This typically is associated with an elevated lactic acid due to decreased perfusion from shock.  
❌ Elevated serum calcium:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Hypocalcemia may be seen in this condition.  
❌ Elevated serum bicarbonate:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of toxic shock syndrome. Metabolic acidosis, and thus a low serum bicarbonate level, would be expected in this condition.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man is diagnosed with Gram-positive bacteremia and started on intravenous Antibiotic X. After admission to the hospital, the patient is given a loading dose of the medication. Afterward, he is scheduled to receive additional injections every six hours. Information regarding Antibiotic X’s pharmacokinetics is listed below. The patient’s body weight is 75 kg, and the target plasma concentration for Antibiotic X is 30 mg/L. Which of the following maintenance doses should be administered?  

Pharmacokinetic Parameter
Value
Volume of distribution  
0.4 L/kg  
Dosing interval  
6 hours  
Bioavailability*  
100%  
Elimination rate  
2.6 L/h  
*For intravenous administration
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with Gram-positive bacteremia and started on Antibiotic X, administered via an intermittent dosing regimen. In emergency cases, a loading dose (a large dose given at the beginning of treatment) can be administered to help the medication rapidly achieve target concentrations. Maintenance doses, given at scheduled intervals, can be subsequently administered to help keep the drug level at a steady-state concentration. The maintenance dose can be calculated via the equation above.

The maintenance dose of Antibiotic X can be calculated as follows:

   Maintenance dose = (30 mg/L * 2.6 L * 6 h) / 100% = 468 mg / 1 = 468 mg = ~470 mg

Therefore, 470 mg of Antibiotic X should be administered every 6 hours to help maintain the desired target plasma concentration.
 

Option Analysis

❌ 180 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: The maintenance dose can be calculated by multiplying the target plasma concentration, clearance rate, and dosing interval and dividing by the drug’s bioavailability. In the case of Antibiotic X, the patient should take a maintenance dose of 470 mg every six hours to keep the plasma drug concentration at 30 mg/L.  
❌ 250 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: A maintenance dose of 470 mg should be given every 6 hours to achieve a plasma drug concentration of 30 mg/L. In contrast, a dose of 250 mg every 6 hours would be insufficient.  
✅ 470 mg every 6 hours:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 600 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: A maintenance dose of 470 mg should be given every 6 hours to achieve a plasma drug concentration of 30 mg/L. In contrast, a dose of 600 mg every 6 hours would cause the actual plasma concentration to be more than the targeted goal.  
❌ 730 mg every 6 hours:
Incorrect: The maintenance dose can be calculated by multiplying the target plasma concentration, clearance rate, and dosing interval and dividing by the drug’s bioavailability. In the case of Antibiotic X, a maintenance dose of 470 mg should be given every six hours to keep the plasma drug concentration at 30 mg/L.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of fever, chills, and generalized malaise. The patient underwent a cystoscopy three weeks ago for hematuria. Past medical history is significant for recurrent cystitis, mitral valve prolapse, and type II diabetes. Current medications include metformin and NPH insulin. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse 99/min, respirations 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> 96% on room air. On physical examination, there are tender erythematous nodules at the fingertips. Cardiac auscultation shows a 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Blood cultures are drawn, and the patient is initiated on an antibiotic that inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portions of the cell wall precursors. The patient does not respond to this antibiotic therapy. Which antibiotic resistance mechanisms are likely responsible for this treatment failure?

choices.text: Poor interaction with binding proteins at the bacterial cell wall
Amino acid modification at the bacterial cell wall

questions.solution:
This patient has a fever, tender nodules, and a holosystolic murmur with a history of mitral valve prolapse. Given this patient’s history of complicated cystitis, there may be urinary tract colonization with Enterococcus or bacterial seeding (leading to bacteremia) from the recent cystoscopy. These findings are concerning for infective endocarditis.

Vancomycin is a commonly used antibiotic for the empiric treatment of endocarditis. It is bactericidal and inhibits bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. Vancomycin is effective against most gram-positive organisms, including multidrug-resistant organisms such as methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA). It is indicated in the treatment of endocarditis, possible MRSA infection, sepsis of unknown source, and many others. Vancomycin can only be given intravenously for systemic infections, as the oral form does not get absorbed well and is only used to treat C. difficile colitis. Adverse effects include nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, diffuse flushing (red man syndrome), and, very rarely, DRESS syndrome.

Vancomycin is not susceptible to beta-lactamases. Resistance mechanisms to vancomycin have been observed with enterococcal species via amino acid modification of D-Ala-D-Ala to D-Ala- D-Lac, to which vancomycin binds with significantly lower affinity.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Poor interaction with binding proteins at the bacterial cell wall:
Incorrect: Drugs such as methicillin bind to the PBP/transpeptidases that crosslink mucopeptides to form the bacterial cell wall. Alterations mediate methicillin resistance in penicillin-binding proteins that reduce the affinity of beta-lactam agents to these proteins.  Methicillin does not bind directly to the D-Ala-D-Ala amino acid precursors of the cell wall.  
❌ Increased efflux from the cell:
Incorrect: Resistance to tetracyclines is due to increased efflux or reduced uptake into bacterial cells by plasmid-encoded transport pumps. Tetracyclines do not inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis and are not used in treating bacterial endocarditis.  
✅ Amino acid modification at the bacterial cell wall:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mutation in DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit the prokaryotic enzyme topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase). Mutations mediate resistance to quinolones to bacterial DNA gyrase. These drugs do not inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis.  
❌ Enzymatic degradation of the drug:
